Note: I'm a Xennial--part of the micro-generation wedged snugly between Gen-X and Millennials. (I sometimes accept the title of "Elder Millenial," but for the most part have trouble relating to those born after 1996.) I picked up this book because I'd noticed a perplexing--sometimes extreme--fragility in some younger millennial and Gen-Y acquaintances, and have been seeking an explanation for this--largely out of concern for what appears to be a corresponding decline in mental health.The authors both lean left of center politically, by their own admission. But this actually adds a lot of credence to their critique and observation of what is essentially an extreme left ideology underpinning this phenomenon. They are SO painfully polite and delicate about presenting their case, padding words to the point where they refer to distorted and toxic ways of thinking as believing "Untruths"--rather than the more direct and obvious choice: LIES. And so it seems they are legitimately attempting to appeal to the very generation and subgroup that's sparked their concern over the future of free speech.“Free speech and the ability to tolerate offense are the hallmarks of a free and open society.” The Three Untruths: 1. The Untruth of Fragility: "What doesn’t kill you makes you weaker."2. The Untruth of Emotional Reasoning: "Always trust your feelings."3. The Untruth of Us vs. Them: "Life is a battle between good people and evil people."The authors point out that these three "untruths," when embraced by students and then reinforced by well-meaning parents and/or overly accomodating University faculty, work as a sort of reverse CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy)--rewiring the brain for maladaptive frailty and higher susceptibility to cognative distortions. Which, of course, results in increased anxiety and depression.The 3 criteria for an Untruth: • Contradicts ancient wisdom. • Contradicts modern psychological research on well-being. • Harms the individuals and communities who embrace it.The authors identify six contributing factors they believe have given rise to this culture of "safetyism," each of which receives its own chapter. 1. Escalating political polarization (campuses shifting leftward and increasingly distrusted by those on the right.)2. An increase in adolescent anxiety and depression beginning in 2011, significantly correlating to smartphone usage/screen time/social media. 3. Paranoid parenting resulting in far less unsupervised play and greater fears of abduction (though rates for this crime have dropped).4. The decline of free play + the rise of focus on test preparation.5. The expansion of a safetyism bureaucracy at universities--driven by federal mandates, risks of lawsuits, and consumerist mentality.6. The quest for justice, evoked by events between 2012 and 2018 that sometimes focuses on "equal outcomes social justice" (in which any demographic disparity is assumed to be the result of discrimination, and any alternative explanations are considered discriminatory.)There are times this book does drag on a bit, and perhaps begins to feel like an overstuffed essay. But they did include a number of accounts I hadn't heard anything about, and their course correction suggestions are both needed and valid. Favorite Quote:"Argue as if you're right, but listen as if you're wrong (and be willing to change your mind). Make the most respectful interpretation of the other person's perspective. Acknowledge where you agree with your critics and what you've learned from them."

This book made my top 10 nonfiction list of 2021! Check out the video here: https://youtu.be/TByaMqiy4JQI appreciated this book on multiple levels. First, I appreciated the message. I think the arguments presented here are thoughtful and important. Second, I appreciated the amount of research done and presented to support the arguments and how they are structured throughout the book. The authors’ present an idea, or a thesis, give anecdotes to highlight it, provide data and research to support it, offer advice on how to combat it, and then recap it all before moving to the next argument. Nice. Third, I appreciated the tone. This isn’t a book about blaming anyone, it’s a book that’s sharing and illustrating specific societal concerns and trying to encourage better interpersonal relations. I think it practices what it preaches.The main thrust of the arguments here are built around what the authors’ label ‘the three great untruths,’ which are: fragility, emotional reasoning, us vs. them mentality. They go into great detail to examine each of these tenets, explaining how and why they’ve become issues, anecdotal examples demonstrating the issues, research and statistics that support their arguments, and potential ways to lessen their impact.This book covers a wide range of topics including: overprotective parents, the effects of social media and too much screentime, the benefits of outdoor play, victim mentality, the struggle with free speech on modern college campuses, and many others.I’ve read quite a few other perspectives on this book. Some complain that the book is repetitive and drawn out, and that it should have remained an article. I think there’s some truth to this. If the arguments they are presenting don’t resonate, chances are this book will wear on you. Another complaint is that the book is narrow minded and only applies to a specific niche of Americans. This I don’t agree with at all. While many of the arguments might use anecdotal evidence from niche elements of American society, I think the broader arguments presented here are important, interesting, and worth reading even if you don’t agree. I don’t even live in America and haven’t in years. I have no interest in politics whatsoever. But I think the message could be valuable even for the high school students I teach in Thailand. In particular, coming into contact with challenging or controversial material, or viewpoints that are contradictory to your own. I can’t stress how much I believe in these ideas as an educator. Life isn’t meant to be easy, nor is it meant to be an echo chamber. Being challenged, failing, and learning how to respond in difficult situations is part of being human, and one of the key ways we learn empathy, in my opinion.In regards to the broad appeal, all three great untruths are in effect with regards to the worldwide covid-19 situation. I think this helps to show that the arguments being presented in this book aren’t just limited to liberal college campuses. Toughening up, learning to interact civilly with people you don’t like or agree with, and focusing on making decisions based on logic and reasoning rather than emotion are values I think anyone could benefit from.Story-8, Language-9, Ideas-10, C-, Enjoyment-8, O8.6

Update: February 22, 2019 - I initially gave this book 4.5 stars, but I am raising its rating. Over the 3 months since I finished The Coddling of the American Mind I cannot believe how many times I have shared the ideas of these authors with others. This book is just so pertinent, so timely, and so important that it comes up again and again. I generally read books and move on to the next so quickly, but this one has found a permanence in my worldview. I think that makes it worthy of 5 stars.Nov 21, 2018Why are so many college students struggling with anxiety and depression? Why are so many university campuses coming up against student demands to disinvite "dangerous" guest speakers, to penalize professors who propone unpopular opinions, and to dismiss any who threaten their conception of safety? This very insightful book discusses 3 great untruths of the "IGen" (the generation born after 1994, coinciding with the ubiquity of the iPhone): The Untruth of Fragility: What doesn’t kill you makes you weaker. The Untruth of Emotional Reasoning: Always trust your feelings. The Untruth of Us Versus Them: Life is a battle between good people and evil people.It shows have parents and institutions have unwittingly taught youth these untruths, and have - with the best of intentions - coddled them to the point of handicapping their ability to handle the adult world. Within this framework, I gained some new insights into the reasons for our increasingly partisan political world.One thing I really like about The Coddling of the American Mind is that, unlike many books of this genre, it doesn't just rip down the system, telling us everything that's wrong with society, then leave us hopeless. Lukianoff and Haidt give pages of good, solid suggestions for how to correct the problems we have created. I would absolutely recommend this book to parents today, as well as to anyone in education or educational administration. It is quite bipartisan, but not afraid to point out problems on both side of the political spectrum. I already put the audiobook on hold for my husband!4.5 stars.

The thesis of this book—CBT solves everything! Kidding.This book is so relevant to the culture that we live in and the future that we are entering into. With its many different antidotes and research, the author does a fantastic job of bringing to the surface different lies (or 'Untruths' as he calls it) that have good intentions but can lead to detrimental effects overall. The stories can definitely get your blood pumping and outrage you at points and I think that's the point. 10/10 would recommend this to most people.One of the best parts of the book is the way the authors write in such a humble and transparent way. The consistently mention how the issues are more complex than they make them out to be and never claim to have the only answer. They also very openly share their political views and how they could influence their own writing when writing about political polarization. So good!

Was under some misapprehensions with this book.I knew the FIRE guys had written it but I thought they were conservative or libertarian. They aren’t.Surprised the book seemed to swerve away from pointing figures at the Left.I was aware of most of the cases they cite so I was feeling less than enlightened.But their adding interesting insights into cognitive psychology and their depressing but accurate take on the various forces that are infantilizing and debilitating today’s youth were cogent and well met.One such insight: kids used to play on unorganized, self selecting ways. They learned to manage their own disputes, their own groups without oversight or a Big Brother.That’s no longer the case.The teens of the sixties hated the college administrators and now Today’s teens look to those same folk to protect them.The causality seems clear.

I’d give it a 3.5. Much necessary wisdom found here. I can clearly remember watching a movie in one of my High School classes about a Jewish attorney defending the rights of American neo-Nazis to hold some sort of rally. (I had to google it, I think it was called Skokie). At the time, I remember being pissed off and confused by the film. Why would a Jewish-American defend the right of someone to speak publicly when the message being delivered was antithetical to your own way of life (or your life itself). It was a complex film, balancing the perspectives of the Jewish community who refused to remain silent (the last time their community failed to speak up they found themselves facing the holocaust) against the views of this Jewish lawyer who argued that the best strategy was to let them speak because counter-protests gave these neo-Nazis exactly what they wanted (publicity). While I have no doubt brain-dumped most of my high school education, this film and the discussion surrounding it had a pretty profound impact on me. It made me appreciate multiple perspectives on controversial subjects and the importance and value of free speech. Plus it forced me to think through how I would handle such a scenario. It was a pretty mind-expanding exercise. The Coddling of the American Mind explores the recent trend toward avoiding these types of discussions at all costs. The move to create “safe spaces” where controversial thoughts and ideas are banned so as not to make anybody ever feel any discomfort. The fact that this type of trend is occurring on college campuses, where students are supposed to have their pre-existing thoughts and beliefs challenged and where rational debate should reign supreme, is even more disturbing. The author argues that there are 3 great “untruths” that have found a home on modern college campuses:1.	Fragility – what doesn’t kill you makes you weaker.2.	Emotional Reasoning (always trust your feelings)3.	Us vs Them (life is a battle between good and evil people (and you are clearly one of the good ones)).While I consider myself, classically liberal, in modern parlance I lean conservative. As most modern institutions (with a few exceptions) are dominated by the political left, this problem has been very apparent to me for some time. So in some respects the authors are preaching to the choir with me. The fact that the book was written by two (modern) “liberals” means the problem has finally become so apparent that it can no longer be ignored. The authors cover a lot of ground in this book, from helicopter parenting (safetyism), to the rampant mental health crisis among young adults (stripped of the healthy upbringing provided in conservative institutions (stable 2-parent families, church/synagogue/Mosque, etc), to modern trolls like Milo Yiannopoulos (who, similar to the Nazis in the film above, gain from and revel in the publicity from their outlandish appearances and counter protests far more than if they were permitted to make their speeches on campus in peace), to the prevalence of group think (with its penchant for sudden onset witch hunts to root out enemies), to the inability of modern educational institutions and the so called adults who run them to stand up to their own students caught up in the fury of (insert latest moral outrage or crusade). Overall, I think the authors did a commendable job of highlighting the current trends and offering solutions on how to prepare your children to overcome, despite the current environment. Would highly recommend. 4 stars.

I already know that this is my favorite book of 2021. Lukianoff and Haidt have written a book that needs to be read...by everyone! The culture of "safetyism," as they call it, has gotten out of control in the US and people are so easily offended that everyone is always looking for a fight. The authors define coddling as "to treat with extreme or excessive care or kindness." People should not feel the need to constantly walk on eggshells in fear that they will offend someone for saying the smallest little thing. I especially enjoyed Part 3 that went through six big drivers of how we have gotten to where we are today - 1) The polarization cycle, 2) anxiety & depression among teens, 3) paranoid parenting, 4) the decline of play, 5) the bureacracy of safetyism and 6) the quest for justice. There are an incredible amount of "mic drops," here are some of my favorites...Favorite quotes:p. 23 - "Many of the important systems in our economic and political life are like our immune systems: they require stressors and challenges in order to learn, adapt, and grow. Systems that are antifragile become rigid, weak, and inefficient when nothing challenges them or pushes them to respond vigorously."p. 41 - "It is not good a good idea to start by assuming the worst about people and reading their actions as uncharitably as possible. This is the distortion known as mind reading; if done habitually and negatively, it is likely to lead to despair, anxiety, and a network of damaged relationships."p. 55 - "One should interpret other people's statements in their best, most reasonable form, not in the worst or most offensive way possible."p. 108 - "Solidarity engenders trust, teamwork, and mutual aid. But it can also foster groupthink, orthodoxy, and a paralyzing fear of challenging the collective."p. 132 - "Negative partisanship means American politics is driven less by hope and more by the Untruth of Us Versus Them. 'They' must be stopped, at all costs."p. 167 - "American parenting is now wildly out of sync with the actual risk that strangers pose to children."p. 237 - "Prepare the child for the road, not the road for the child."p. 240 - "Learning to give and take criticism without being hurt is an essential life skill."p. 259 - "A community in which members hold one another accountable for using evidence to substantiate their assertions is a community that can, collectively, pursue truth in the age of outrage."

There was a time when I was a youthful idealist, full of love and hope for humanity. These days, sometimes the only guard against misanthropy in my possession is recognition that we’re all broken creatures – in the gutter, as Oscar Wilde might say. But to follow on his epigram…if some of us are looking at the stars from that gutter, what are the rest looking at? In The Coddling of the American Mind, Greg Lukianoff and Jonathan Haidt argue that a new philosophy has made itself predominant in American, and increasingly western, culture — and that it rests on three untruths, promoted in schools, by parents, and enforced by the rest of society. Not only is it driving depression and anxiety, it also foments violence in the streets. Coddling is an insightful, sometimes depressing, but ultimately hopeful look at why people have sunk to such lows in recent years, and how we can rise again to assume the dignity of human beings – and treat each other likewise. It begins with a visit to the guru of Stupid – or rather, ‘Koalemos’, as the authors open the book by recounting their visit to a guru in the Greek hinterlands who taught three things:  What doesn’t kill you makes you weaker.  Always trust your feelings.  Always assume the worst about other people, for the war is divided between good and evil people. If the curious reader googles Koalemos, s/he will discover that said deity was the Greek god of stupid. The guru, as it happens, is fictional; a rhetorical invention. But his untruths are taught still – by our schools, at all levels – and increasingly encouraged throughout society, from parenting strategies to government policy. The untruths are manifestly destructive, sabotaging self-development and inculcating anxiety, depression, and paranoia. One of the authors, Greg Lukianoff, reveals far into the text that he once very nearly committed suicide; he was able to recover his mental health by learning to identify the ways his own mind was poisoning itself, through self-defeating ways of thinking. He learned to use CBT, a psychological tactic very kin to Stoic mindfulness, to break loose of his worst inclinations. The great untruths, he couldn’t help but notice, operated the same way his former destructive mental habits did.  Lukianoff and Haidt believe the initial popularity of these untruths came from an obsession for safety that overtook parents of the eighties and nineties – spurred by the crime spike of that era, and several public health crises. But overprotection can be deadly; an immune system that doesn’t get tested early on will become self-destructive later on, resulting in autoimmune disorders and rampant increases in food allergies. We are, Lukianoff and Haidt write, anti-fragile creatures: we not only find strength in resistance, we need resistance and danger if we are to grow at all. What the modern world is continuing to build for itself, however, is a world where people are expected to be completely sheltered from not only what might hurt them, but what they imagine hurts them. Somehow, we have fallen from being watchful for bad actors, and become paranoid about opinions which go against ours, or disrupt our peace of mind. We’ve become like the people in Fahrenheit 451, wanting to lose ourselves in fantasy and throwing into the fire anything that disrupts the dream.This book can be thoroughly depressing, infuriating, or otherwise dispiriting in several chapters, but never moreso when chronicling the campus riots and unrest of the 20-teens, as ‘student’ bodies rushed to de-platform or get fired anyone they disagreed with – including professors who were their ideological allies. Haidt & Lukianoff document this kind of hysterical childishness on both sides, though as one ideological bent dominates college, it pops up proportional more in this view. But Haidt & Lukianoff are not talk-show hosts or polemicists casting a mocking eye at this fracas and scoffing at them: they present it at the same time as they present figures on growing rates of suicide, depression, and mental health disorders among the young. Something is deeply wrong here. The authors then explore various contributing factors; the cult of safety being one, but supported by a maniacal obsession with college, one that often begins in kindergarten as overzealous parents try to get their little ones working on their college resumes before they’ve mastered the art of Play-Doh. Another giant problem in this mental health arena is that the present generation has been wholly reared on devices. The ramifications of obsessive screentime are still being studied, thirteen years after Steve Jobs opened that particular pandora’s box, but device usage has already been linked to growing rates of depression, as people’s doting on social media timelines convinces them that they’re not as popular, and their lives not as good, as the peers around them. Is there a way out of this? Lukianoff & Haidt hope so. They note that some of the masters of social media are pretending to care about their products’ role in damaging mental health and fomenting radicalization, and there are growing enclaves of people who realize how unsustainable giving into childish mobs on campuses every other week is – who realize that the purpose of a university is to push young people to become more than they are, to refine their dross – not to patronize their worse impulses. There are parents, too, who realize children need freedom to grow….that exercising autonomy is a necessary experience. Unfortunately, parents in this regard have to work in tandem with local governments, since there exist cretins masquerading as humans who will call the police if they see a child playing outside on her own. Ultimately, Haidt and Lukianoff write, Americans need to restore the culture of dignity over the culture of victimhood – to push for social justice along common identity, not common enemy, lines. Treat a man as your enemy and he will become one. The Coddling of the American Mind is a most helpful book, helping readers understand the chaos around us without dismissing its participants as universal bad actors. Much of what has happened, what continues to happen, is driven by people with the best of intentions – but good intentions count for little when the consequences are quite this bad. Although it’s not as eye-opening and insightful as The Righteous Mind, Haidt’s previous work, it’s not too far from its neighborhood. It is especially relevant into today’s hysteria over COVID and racially-linked police deaths, as people tar and feather those whose opinions differ from their own. We can have calm discussions on the efficacy of masks, or on the nature of death-by-cops, or we can scream “YOU JUST WANT PEOPLE TO DIE” at each other. One course is more helpful.

I liked this book much more than I expected to. I was already familiar with Haidt's previous work, and with Lukianoff's. I'd also read their Atlantic article on this topic. I'm not usually a fan of articles turned into books, and was expecting to read a lot of things that I'd already heard before. But there's actually a *lot* packed into this book. There's a great chapter here that nicely summarizes some of the more notable campus crises of the Evergreen State/Berkeley Riot variety. There's a very good chapter on recent increases in teen anxiety and depression. There's a pair of excellent chapters on the dangers of overparenting and the importance of free play. And there's a lot of good insights into "anti fragility" and the need for children and young adults to be able to grow from challenging experiences. I'd love to get a copy of this book into every college administrator's hands. It's a very readable, very wise, and very important book.

HUTCHINGS BOOK CLUB MARCH 2023*Slightly rounded up, closer to 4.5If I had read this book in 2018 when it came out, my opinion of it would have been completely different. With the past five years of context between its publishing and now, I think the research in this book and many (not all) of the authors’ points have been strengthened with the distance. I do think good things with good intentions can always be driven too far in one direction to no longer be helpful— especially if dialogue and conversations are squelched in the process. Being a current college instructor and a former high school teacher, I have spent almost a decade educating Gen Z students and much of the critiques and concerns mentioned here have mirrored my own experiences and feelings. I didn’t expect to reflect on my parenting in this book, but that was another positive element! Books backed by research that make the readers think and question their own beliefs are winners to me, even if all points don’t personally resonate.
A great, analytical read if you are interested in society polarization, over-fragility, and how parents, teachers, and universities can help reducing those issues.

This book was especially interesting to me as I am raising iGen'ers. The Coddling of the American Mind is absolutely superb. It's engaging, thought-provoking, clear-cut and complete. One of the best books I've ever read.The premise of 'The Coddling' is that we're experiencing a significant shift in culture regarding raising and educating children. It is a shift towards keeping them more safe and sheltered, not only from physical dangers but increasingly from ideas and opposing views. However well-intended by parents, politicians and teachers, the phenomenon of 'safetyism' is ultimately doing more harm than good, setting up new generations for a future of failure. We would be wise to abandon these ideas altogether in favor of parenting and teaching styles that result in more resilient and able minded (young) adults.'The Coddling' is incredibly well-written and persuasive, but what makes it stand out are its structure and conciseness. The book can be divided into four major parts, each logically following the other. The first part is dedicated to describing the phenomenon of safetyism, and proving it actually exists. It answers questions such as 'what is exactly happening?' and 'how much is it happening?'. The following chapter makes a case for why it is bad to be happening, and how bad it could get in the future. Next, it gives likely explanations to explain 'how could this happen?'. Lastly, the authors provide solutions to the problem to tell us 'how can we solve this and prevent worse from happening?'. Each part is subdivided into smaller chapters, always properly introducing and summarizing, perfectly encasing its contents within the framework of said section. It's almost impossible to not follow the contents when the structure is so solid, even when listening to the book on tape.Secondly, the authors did an amazing job of being as concise as possible. 'The Coddling' is not a quick read, yet not a word is too much (or too little, for that matter). It never becomes tedious, and never leaves you longing for more examples or information. It provides the right amount of arguments; a solid combination of anecdotes, analogies, scientific data and relevance in psychology, the field of expertise of author Haidt. The style of writing is precise, explaining and defining concepts when referenced, and doesn't become pretentious or too technical even when going in depth on difficult subjects. Combined with the clear structure, it makes for an easy-to-follow book, which is quite an accomplishment for such a complex and controversial theme.It's hard for me to point out possible improvements for this book. I've read people's claims that it's too focused on the wrongdoings of the political Left, but I strongly disagree with that sentiment. 'The Coddling' gives plenty of examples on wrongs of both Left and Right, and doesn't stray too far into either territory. Some reviewers say that the subject matter is exaggerated, not being as big of a problem as the authors make it out to be. That argument only holds ground if you consider the numerous excesses, such as Evergreen College students holding teachers hostage or the rise of safe spaces and free speech restrictions, currently acceptable. To me it's perfectly obvious that we're dealing with a serious problem and potential threat for our future, and this book convinced me even more. Perhaps my critique is that the authors can be a bit too lenient on certain excesses, giving even someone who calls for white genocide the benefit of the doubt that they don't literally mean killing people. However, this is mostly me nitpicking to find some flaws, and it certainly doesn't take anything away from a nearly perfect book.The Coddling of the American Mind is a brilliant book. It's complete and concise, well-structured, persuasive yet nuanced, and grasps the reader from the very first page. Recommended to anyone with some responsibility for children, or who cares about their (and our) future.

Although the authors shoot several bullseyes, the book's analysis of the phenomenon of Generation Triggered is a bit confused and scattershot. Not quite as good as I had every reason to expect. The authors undoubtedly come from a place of concern and understanding. The fine people at the Heterodox Academy have highlighted important social trends around campus speech codes, trigger warnings, emotional reasoning, identity politics, the psychopathology of (self-enforced) mental fragility, etc... This book is a testament to that worrying and often puzzling empirical reality, and the first decent attempt at exorcising its demons. The faults of the book, however, undermine the coherence and credibility of the overall analysis. The three big ones are...1) An inability or unwillingness to provide a big causal story that makes sense. Quality is replaced by quantity. Everything gets blamed from bad parenting to school administrators to academic ideologies. No doubt all of these are important trends. I just don't find the "shotgun" method of analysis particularly helpful in pinpointing the ROOT causes of the problem. 2) A failure to seek to understand the philosophical and moral foundations of radical egalitarianism, transgressive social norms, the discourse on power, etc... For a proper understanding, one would have to read and understand Marx, Marcuse, Foucault, Derrida, Butler, etc. This is beyond the interests of the authors. We are thus left with a muddled narrative that replaces philosophy with psycho(patho)logy. This can illuminate some important aspects of the campus madness but not unearth its parallel metaphysical foundations.3) As a consequence of the descriptive psychopathological focus, the normative emphasis on cognitive-behavioural therapy follows naturally. CBT, while worthwhile as a general tool of self-improvement, may be partially misplaced as a particular remedy to identity politics and social justice wars. It psychologizes and infantilizes one's opponents (see point #2 above), and fails to address the root causes of tribalism, moral righteousness, and extremism. Nazism was not defeated by therapy but by guns and propaganda, and the Berlin Wall required half a century to come down. CBT could not have done the job, since ideology is different from psychic illness. Not even the best of self-help advice will be able to solve the trans rights or abortion or global warming debate. Only a prolonged ethical-political debate will, which is why free speech is so important. For all its faults, the book carries an important message on how to secure free speech. In addition, it offers some uncalled for but eminently useful practical advice on how to cure combative millennials. The book lacks robustness as a coherent thesis and therefore misses the final landing by a mile. But at least it manages to take off in a bold new direction over the horizon that is bound to attract more and better equipped Amelia Earharts.

I've been a bit worried about the things I hear about the "campus left": how there are protests at the campuses whenever some right-winger has been called to give a lecture, and how these protests have at times turned violent. How students are demanding the classes can't contain triggering materials, to the point of making teaching certain subjects nigh-impossible. How professors can get fired because their emails contain words that are deemed not sensitive enough. Etc. I'm sure you know the phenomenon. And since what happens in America now can happen here in North Europe after a slight delay, I decided to read Lukianoff's and Haidt's book about the subject to understand the situation better - and perhaps be prepared for the rise of the campus left in my own country.The book has a brilliant structure. First the authors describe the three "Great Untruths" they fell the iGen have fallen prey to:1) What doesn't kill you makes your weaker2) Always trust your emotions3) The world is a fight between the Good people and the Evil people.Then they show examples of these untruths in action: basically an in expanded list of the activities of the campus left I mentioned above.By this point, the reader is shaking their head and willing to call off the whole generation. But then Lukianoff and Haidt turn the tables when they start to explore WHY the campus activists do such messed up things: they point their finger to alt-right and right-wing demagogues, who have been stirring up hate and polarization for a decade or more; helicopter parents who don't let their kids play freely, so they don't grow into responsible adults; lawmakers and administrators, who try to minimize the risks and take safety to ridiculous levels. Basically L&H say that if the kids aren't alright, it's the fault of their parents' and other members of the previous generations - so you shouldn't blame the students, but look for solutions. The last chapter is then dedicated on the possible solutions to the problems.After reading this book I'm much less worried about the campus left I was earlier. Many issues seem to be wholly American: the idea that second-grade kids wouldn't be safe walking alone to and from school is very alien to Finns. We also don't have popular far-right talk show hosts or anything similar. If Lukianoff and Haidt are right in their analysis, the situation in campuses here shouldn't become as dire as in the USA.

A very thought provoking read. Caveat, I don't believe the examples cited in the book are entirely indicative of the overall population of the younger generations (Gen Y, Gen Z). That being said, it is a raw depiction of the current status of the victim mentality and calling out that is happening in society today - and not just the aforementioned generations.In the early phase of reading I was trying to figure out if Haidt and Lukianoff lean left or right. They do a pretty thorough job of tossing stones at each side, so it is difficult to tell. No spoiler alert, they do disclose somewhere around page 180 or so. And, it is a bit of a surprise.What they do is discuss the nonsensical thinking of over-political correctness as it treads too far from reality. Further, they discuss how that has lead to the "other side" reacting as they have and the neo-rise of the alt-right.Also, the stories they tell of some of the incidents on campuses over the past 5 - 8 years is rather disturbing. I was actually getting a bit worked up reading these very objective stories. With an 8th grader who is already thinking about "college" some day, it was unsettling for a parent to read this stuff.Then, they revert back to the initial "Three Great Untruths" and use that as a basis of how to move forward. Their analysis doesn't "solve" the problem, and some other commenters have castigated the authors for this. That IS the point, you need to understand how other groups think to seek to understand, not seek to respond. I have always believed this, but this is a book that helps hammer the point home.Frankly, I think this was a great book - being rocked a bit off center is how we grow. They discuss at the end of the book the purpose of education it to find TRUTH - as many colleges have in their mottos (along with knowledge). Well, with all the homogenized worlds being created and filtered due to social media and polarized news, we need much more of TRUTH and KNOWLEDGE and seeking to understand BEFORE we react, and not just seeking to respond.I highly recommend this book if you are willing to think while reading, pausing from time to time, and applying these understandings to all the people around you. Get away from the Us vs. Them mentality being produced in the media factories we follow today. Have the courage to learn that your assertions may be not 100% right and the other side is NOT 100% wrong. Basically, have the courage to allow yourself to be wrong.

I don't trust any of these slick jaspers in their split-back coats, with their gelled hair; their wide, toothy smirks; their promise of 'secret insights'; their bullet-points and catchphrases.Trained public speakers are always in the business of selling snake-oil. Brilliant brilliant brilliant! I dont remember a book that I would highlight this intensively. Now I can understand the problems western societies face today at a much deeper scale. "Safetyism is the cult of safety — an obsession with eliminating threats (both real and imagined) to the point at which people become unwilling to make reasonable trade-offs demanded by other practical and moral concerns. Overall one of the best reads of the year. I highly recommend it to anybody who might be seeking some root-cause knowledge on how to understand the current society of American. That said, I find it a bit less exciting reading through the second half of this book (part 3 and above) compared with the earlier half. Thinking about it, it feels that the tone is a lot more definitive in the 2nd half. The authors, obviously with the best intent out there, became rather prescriptive in what fixes should happen. Obviously, their prescriptions might work. Or they might not. I think that there's no simple thinking or answer to this very complex problem - and the affective polarization is not really a contemporary American only problem, but a human society problem - for it's closely related to our basic human needs such as "belongings", "group thinking", "feeling supported", so on and so forth. I wish the book tried to dive a bit deeper into examples in other countries and in other era. I wish it did not end up in a way as if it was a simple problem to solve as long as people followed their prescription (which is not true, IMHO).

Lukianoff and Haidt seem like the type of liberals that would have voted for Obama for a third term but also might be fine with throwing some people into the sunken place because, you know, what doesn't kill you makes you tougher.Overall, while I probably agree with some ideas, like free range parenting and giving yourself some challenges so you know how to handle adversity, they speak from an upper middle class life that makes it super easy to tell others that we can solve all our problems with a nice conversation and good intentions. They are part of a larger tradition of an older generation telling a younger generation they are not doing things right and are going to ruin America. Somehow I think the kids will be alright.

While reading this: 😳 😱 😬 🙊 🙉 After I finished: 🤯 Three days later... "well, that book changed everything." I recommend this book to everyone, especially parents and college students... and people who try to be polite/politically correct/say the right thing. It's good to be considerate of others, but excessive care-taking and coddling doesn't help them... or you.

This was written, in a nutshell, as a response to the growing incidents of college students having meltdowns and tantrums on campus. The authors are Cognitive Behavior Therapists (and center/center-left politically) and have observed how Gen Z has been raised in exactly the opposite of Cognitive Behavior Therapy principles, leaving them emotionally and mentally weak and unprepared for adulthood. The book explores “Three Great Untruths”:– What Doesn’t Kill You Makes You Weaker (Truth: Being shielded from discomfort and hardship your whole life makes you unable to function as an adult.)– Always Trust Your Feelings (Truth: Feelings often don’t reflect reality. “I can’t do anything right.” “That person looked at me, so they want to hurt me.” “If I don’t pass this test, my whole life is ruined.” These are all lies.)– Life Is a Struggle of Us Vs. Them (Truth: While it easy to put people in categories, taken to an extreme, this is dangerous for society. If you stop and talk to people with the intent to understand, you will discover you agree on a lot more than you thought you did.)Parenting shifted in the early 80s with “America’s Most Wanted” convincing parents that predators were everywhere despite it being a safer time than the 60s. The overreaction led to helicopter parenting and “Safetyism,” the belief that people must be shielded from anything that hurts them physically, mentally, and emotionally. This not only stunts growth in these areas, it is in opposition to democracy and liberty.If you don’t learn to control your feelings and recognize harmful thinking, especially catastrophizing, you are easily manipulated by others because you’re easily offended and worried what people think of you. If you seek for “microaggressions” everywhere, you are seeing people as enemies and constantly worried about what others think of you. You are always catastrophizing, and then we get this “words are literal violence” nonsense. This is terrible for mental health. I’ve met young people who don’t even believe it’s possible to control your feelings. That’s part of growing up. Related to that, society rewards victims and sees achievement as oppression. To avoid being bullied, you have to portray yourself as a victim first.One example in the book was a tweet someone wrote that said they wanted a “white genocide.” Many people were offended or appalled at such a call to violence. But when you learn what it really means, it’s something else: The tweeter was referring to the fear of white supremacists that the white race will disappear (a “genocide”) because of interracial relationships. The tweeter was poking fun at those people, not calling for mass violence. Note how we don’t communicate anymore, don’t speak the same language, and perceive each other more and more as “other” and “bad.”I feel I should offer one little correction: The book talks about Trump’s Charlottesville speech that got a lot of people riled up, but it left out part of Trump’s statement, which he repeated about three times: “There were some good people who showed up to condemn the removal of statures. I’m not talking about the white nationalists and white supremacists; those people should all be condemned.”My rant on racism: The concept of racism is so stupid, so illogical, that I don’t think it has a place on the political spectrum. (Progressives got into it with eugenics, but even now most progressives don’t go for it.) I don’t think racism fits with the term “far right.” There is nothing conservative or right-wing about racism. Conservatism believes everybody has equal value and needs equal opportunities. Everyone has personal challenges that can be overcome. No one deserves either legal favoritism nor discrimination for surface, immutable characteristics. Now, I tend to be naïve in thinking no one could be so stupid to believe in racism, and my mind has a hard time believing that racism is any serious threat to anyone because surely there aren’t that many morons among us. So I apologize if I ever appear to dismiss racism as not a big deal. Really, it’s just incomprehensible to some part of my brain.Language: MildSexual Content: Mentions of consent issues; nothing explicitViolence/Gore: Riots, protestsHarm to Animals: NoneHarm to Children: Mentions of abductions, helicopter parentingOther (Triggers): Cancel culture, false accusations, overreaction

I rarely give 5 stars to any book but this one was a standout for me. I think every parent, school administrator and teacher would benefit by reading this book right now. It's been on my to-read list for a while and I wish I had read it when it was first released 3 years ago. I actually listened to the audio version and have since bought the physical book so I can highlight and mark it and pass it on for my kids to read.I appreciated that it was a thoughtful, logical, data-based book with clear assessments and solutions. Their basis is that people have been trying to help kids and protect them and it's back firing in some ways (though not all). It's from a very positive position and recognizes that the intents have been good which I appreciated. I had a friend say she thought that reading this book would just verify her own thoughts and be like an echo chamber. I found there were some points that did agree with my previous assumptions (like the fact that we are trying to protect children way too much and it's hurting their ability to become confident adults) but I still gained from the explanation of studies done that showed why it's destructive and what it's actually doing.I gained new insights into why there is a distinct uptick in animosity on college campuses and how and why diversity there is decreasing which will lead to more problems, why depression and anxiety are skyrocketing in teens, why there has been an explosion of riots around the nation and how both Democrats and Republicans have exacerbated the problems but the roots of the anger is more likely from our feelings of tribalism rather than inclusion and from our inability to listen and debate with those who have different ideas from us without feeling personally attacked. We need to always give the benefit of the doubt! I even learned why there has been an exponential rise in peanut allergies (which I've been trying to figure out for years!). I feel like I have been shaking my head for the last few years going why, why, why? And this book gave many reasons that resonated as truths and logical causes.I truly appreciated that it ends with a list of specific ideas that we can all do to improve ourself, our kids, our communities and America as a whole. I loved the suggestions to improve mental health. I usually hate books where people tell me what to do so this was surprising to me that I loved their suggestions and wholeheartedly agreed with them.A little more than halfway through the book, when it got to a chapter about social division and would be addressing some political topics, the authors wanted to make clear their political leanings since they had already discussed how we all have biases and they wanted to be upfront. I was thrilled to learn that one generally supports the Democratic party and the other leans more to Libertarian (I think I am remembering that correctly - I listened to the book) and neither has ever voted for a Republican in any national election. Since I am much more conservative, (though I've felt partyless lately and don't like to claim Republican right now) I was thrilled because I had been nodding my head and agreeing with so much of the book already and to know that we were coming from different sides of the aisle just made me happy and confirmed to me that they were writing as logically and unbiased as possible to address this book to everyone.This is the longest review I've ever written but I was really impressed by this book and I think if everyone can recognize the causes for the effects we are already seeing then they will be motivated to make changes that will curb the trend, strengthen our children, improve colleges and we can become again a united America - still with different ideas and priorities but able to listen to each other and work together for the common good. Read this book. I don't think you will regret it.

I thought Haidt's The Righteous Mind was excellent (my review). In fact it's probably one of my top reads of 2021. But Coddling of the American Mind didn't click. Stuff I liked:- The three Great Untruths and their dangers: what doesn't kill you makes you weaker, always trust your feelings, life is a battle between good and evil people. - The first untruth is based on Antifragile - one of my favourite books. - Chapter 2 ("always trust your feelings") talked about using Cognitive Behaviour Therapy techniques to analyze your thoughts and feelings for cognitive distortions. I thought this was super useful, and it's something I'll file away for the future. - It was interesting enough throughout to finish. Stuff I didn't like:- Published in 2018 and mostly covering events from 2013-2018, this felt like a book about current events that is a few years out of date. - Too focused on America... I guess I can't complain as it was in the title. - The book is about "outrage and polarization" (p255), particularly on university and college campuses. I find this topic exhausting, draining, and unfulfilling to read about. The whole of Part II was a catalogue of polarizing events which reminded me why I deleted Facebook (in ~2010, a decade before it was cool), and significantly dialed back on outage-prone social media in the last few years (loving the 3rd-party Twitter app Talon for it's "muffle" feature, and the ability to filter out keywords and hastags from your timeline). - The book as a whole, coherent argument somehow didn't click. There are some critical reviews that suggest the 2015 Atlantic article is good enough, and that a book is too much. (note, I have not read the article. No more, please!) Haidt and co-author Lukianoff had about a gentle and balanced approach as possible in discussing this topic, but I just don't have the mental stamina for outrage (news, social media) or meta-outrage (this book).

Education should not be intended to make people comfortable; it is meant to make them think. – Hanna Holborn GrayI look for books that are going to make me think, make me see things differently. Coddling of the American Mind did this. In brief, it is about three great Untruths that are affecting US universities and making them weaker: that we are protecting them from things that they see as dangerous, because – although there are good people, there are also evil ones. The great Untruths are:1. The Untruth of Fragility: What doesn’t kill you makes you weaker. 2. The Untruth of Emotional Reasoning: Always trust your feelings. 3. The Untruth of Us Versus Them: Life is a battle between good people and evil people. (p. 4) Lukianoff and Haidt are provocative, but also good at bringing together diverse kinds of information together to help us recognize, as the subtitle goes, "how good intentions and bad ideas are setting up a generation for failure."For a book about the dichotomous and extreme thinking characterizing parenting, students, and the university system in the 21st century, Lukianoff and Haidt slip into dichotomous thinking. As do we all from time to time.We are in an age of helicopter parenting – even bulldozer parenting – where parents attempt to intervene with their college-aged children in a way that my daughters, frustratingly, would not allow me to do when they were in grade school. Rather than helping them, except in the short-term, this sort of parenting (and overscheduling, failing to allow or encourage free play, etc.) leaves students to becoming fragile, anxious, and easily hurt. Lukianoff and Haidt argue compellingly that college students should and must be exposed to viewpoint diversity, which will help them think more critically, understand diverse perspectives, and withstand events that would otherwise make them depressed and anxious. As the authors conclude, this means that we should beseeking out challenges (rather than eliminating or avoiding everything that “feels unsafe”), freeing yourself from cognitive distortions (rather than always trusting your initial feelings), and taking a generous view of other people, and looking for nuance (rather than assuming the worst about people within a simplistic us-versus-them morality). (p. 14)I appreciated Coddling of the American Mind, but I was often annoyed and irritated by it – which are not good outcomes for this time of year. Lukianoff and Haidt gathered interesting and often compelling threads, but I wasn't convinced by all of their evidence. Clearly, there is more anxiety and depression on campus than when I was in school, but that isn't necessarily a function of "coddling," but of greater access on college campuses. Students who would not have been able to attend college 20 years ago can.While Lukianoff and Haidt criticize students' complaints about controversial and noncontroversial speakers (e.g., George Will, Bill Maher, Eric Holder, Madeleine Albright), I am less dismayed. I like that students are more likely to set limits about things that my generation accepted (e.g., #metoo).Current parenting practices, among many other things, have both strengths and weaknesses. Lukianoff and Haidt primarily focus on the downside here, but maybe we can look for some nuance and attempt to create a stronger model for the next generation of parents – and universities.

This is an important read in today's society. This book is a look at the iGen generation that seems to be obsessed with technology and social media. The authors look at how ready access to news and social media affects attitudes and higher education. iGen students seem to be obsessed with protecting themselves against any other opinion than their own. They are less open to expanding their worldview and listening to opposing views to gain a broader understanding of today's society. This has led to students feeling "unsafe" when dealing with someone who does not share their views. Are they truly physically unsafe or are they just unable to process opposing views? Instead of engaging in open, civil debate or listening to gain understanding, students are sheltered and professors and administrators kowtow to students, offering special "safe spaces," firing faculty who simply exercise their first amendment right, or even canceling guest speakers whose views are not shared with the majority of students. In essence, the authors suggest that we are coddling America's youth and young adults, sheltering them to the point that they are unable to process opinions and ideas that they do not identify with. The authors spend a lot of time discussing how technology and social media have affected current attitudes and lifestyles. Where once young kids would go out and play in the neighborhood, without constant adult supervision, they are today being watched by helicopter parents, suggesting that kids are being overprotected. Are we coddling the younger generations to the point that they are unable to psychologically handle uncomfortable positions? It is certainly worth thinking about and this book will open that discussion to consider if we are doing a disservice to our youth.I think this is a must-read for parents, teachers, and faculty of higher education. These are the children that will one day rule our nation. How will they handle our future?

Though this book contained some repetitive arguments and a few sections that were less compelling than others, it largely succeeded in providing a balanced account of the current state of mental health among American college students as well as the tendency of student activists to perceive situations as "us versus them" conflicts lacking ambiguity or nuance. I certainly see many of the behaviors that the authors track among both the students I work with and my leftist peers online (particularly w/r/t to their tendency to interpret the words of others without the principle of charity and to adhere to the "untruth of fragility").As the authors likely intended, I was surprised and sickened by some of the college campus narratives in here, especially those in which professors I perceive to be intelligent, kind, and invested in social justice are summarily rejected and harassed by activists who (paradoxically) do not seem to see these scholars as real people, but instead as one-dimensional symbols of white supremacy and queerphobia. Though the authors end up addressing many of the counterarguments that came to mind as I read the text, I wish they would have spent a bit more time on what activism when it *doesn't* embody some of the cognitive distortions and concerning groupthink that Haidt and Lukianoff point out. The authors rightly address the fact that activism plays a key role in social progress, but--from what I recall-- only briefly address 60s-era protests as examples of this. Because the internet plays an enormous role in mob mentality/the tendency to perceive everything as a violence, I would have also liked to have seen the authors discuss how discourse communities on Tumblr and Twitter influence youth activism a bit more thoroughly. Overall, though, I found The Coddling of the American Mind to be a cogent examination of a variety of serious issues impacting not just college campuses, but American society/the culture wars in general. I am grateful for the authors' capacity to treat many of the subtopics they include with respect, moderation, and (just as they preach) charity.P.S. I found the theoretical introductory anecdote set in Greece and unveiling of "the great untruths" pretty cringe-y, and believe the book would be better without it.

This book is getting lots of play these days. I think the book is generally well done and the interest in the book is well deserved. Most of my issues with the book stem not from its content but from an effort to do too much within the context of a popular book on secondary and post-secondary education. Do not get me wrong here. The parts of the book all seem on target and well presented. The problem is in how they fit together and how a general reader can get his/her mind around the different parts of the book.Where to start?Going from the title “The Coddling of the American Mind” has broad ambitions to make a statement about American intellectual life, education, social values, and the like. OK, so far so good. But the book jumps in and largely focuses on events at a small number of elite and highly competitive private liberal arts colleges and universities, with a few public universities thrown in for good measure. No claim is made that the events and trends in the book are happening at more than a small number of these schools or that these are common occurrences even within the sample. While this set of schools is obviously important, it is a small subset of American higher education. For a long time, most students who attend and complete college do so at large public institutions and most do not study the traditional “liberal arts” but instead study in fields like business, social work, nursing, and education. So what is on display here is a subset of elite education in America.So this book is a highly visible representative of the genre of “wacky stuff that is going on within America’s elite undergraduate institutions”. Recent members of this genre include Deresiewicz’s “Excellent Sheep”. People my age might remember Bloom’s “The Closing of the American Mind” or could go back to Buckley and “God and Man at Yales”. Why the interest in the elite schools? Well, their alumni certainly read a lot, but there is also some level of intellectual voyeurism at work. And then there are the parents trying to crack the code to gain entry for their kids into these schools. I do not mention this to diminish the value of the book. If anything what happens at these elite schools is of high symbolic value to the rest of American higher education and will likely remain so.Now to the book.The book is a compilation and distilling of a wide range of arguments and research streams but the basic “hook” concerns the recent increase in importance of “three great untruths” - the untruth of fragility, the untruth of emotional reasoning, and the untruth of “us versus them”. These untruths are unjustified assumptions that when incorporated into one’s thinking produce significant and counterintuitive errors of potentially significant dimensions, most notably in the shutting down of speakers and discordant viewpoints for fear of causing emotional harm to those not in agreement or the taking of actions against those holding fringe opinions as a result of their holding such opinions. The central part of the book is a discussion of these errors and of a number of highly disturbing events at various colleges in which these errors are seen as having played a part and which involved intimidation, violence and even academic “witch hunts”.The book then expands on its initial chapters by discussing the role of other stakeholder groups. Few are left out and the book covers faculty, students, administrators, the news media, social media, parents, and secondary school educators (of the college students). The book makes a specific generational claim, namely that the events and trends it chronicles — the “iGen” or “Generation Z”. Yes, this is not a book about millennials but the subsequent generation. (Let me note here that I do not view the generational argument - here or more generally - as a strength of the book and that reducing matters to the lowest demographic temporal common denominator is seldom a compelling basis for argument. The authors themselves note that the trends they cover are not found in everyone starting college - or even a majority.)The book is an outgrowth of a 2014 New Republic article that focused on explaining these disturbing and highly visible events at major institutions.I am generally persuaded that the authors have brought together a relevant set of ideas and trends and that the book is informative about what is going on in colleges today. It certainly rings true with my experience. I am less certain about the incidence and prevalence of the issues that are raised. The examples discussed are not that common although common enough to merit attention.A strength of the book is that it tries to tie together are variety of ideas and trends together and to provide a broader and better integrated perspective than is commonly presented in the popular literature on university life today. If anything, the authors attempt too much. The later chapters on helicopter parents and the demise of play are not particularly informative. The treatment of the role of university administrators in the “coddling” process is plausible and even useful and the focus in the book on universities as complex educational organizations is a valuable.There are gaps too. The book could do more to point out the contributions of professors and niche academic fields to the mess. In fairness, this is a difficult and sensitive issue and all academic work can and should be actively criticized. The authors are spot on in detailing the rise of consumerist approaches to higher education and how that contributes to pathologies. (This problem is also present in graduate professional education.) The authors say virtually nothing about the difficulties that new students have in academically adjusting to college life and how academic demands may interact with newer social demands to produce some of the bizarre behaviors mentioned in the book.Finally, in discussing what to do, it would have been helpful for the authors to explain how some schools prevent outrages from happening my maintain the rights of all to speak and enforcing codes of student behavior (and local laws). Most colleges know how to maintain order while continuing to promote academic values.Overall, these concerns are minor. As these books go, this is a good one and worth reading.

I enjoyed this book, however I wished it dug deeper into explaining how these rifts have formed in our society. I found "What's Our Problem" by Tim Urban to be a more insightful read. A few points this book raised that I found unique and interesting were how the deprivation of unsupervised play and exposure to risk at a young age have affected the youngest generations, which may be part of the cause of the large spike in teenage anxiety and depression. Social media and the rise of political polarization were another two major factors at play here, which I imagine will not subside anytime soon. The prescriptions for improving were not earth shattering, but are always good to be reminded of: start with what you can control (yourself), limit time on your device/social media, practice mindfulness, and let kids play outside. Probably not a bad idea to get some outdoor time as an adult too. Favorite quotes (some not from author but quoted in book)"Prepare the child for the road, not the road for the child""Mass movements can rise and spread without belief in a God, but never without the belief in a devil""One paradox of upper middle class American life is that some of the things parents and schools do to help kids get admitted to college may make them less able to thrive once they're there"

The ideas here are well meaning and admirable. They do appear to genuinely want a better future for students and academics in a world where free speech is under threat. However, in their haughty claims of distanced pragmatism, supposedly different from the moralistic and emotional actions of students and professors, they have their own problems. They have been so caught up in their view, become so absolutist in their denouncement of the modern ‘safetyism’ , that they now have their own cult - not one of safety, but one where stoicism is a righteous expectation of every individual. They liken students to delicate candles, rather than fires, neglecting the fact a student needs a degree of time and protection for that candle to BECOME a fire, especially in a new environment. I think they have some great ideas, and their emphasis of the need for freedom of speech and their advocation of CBT is very valuable. BUT, they amalgamate totally different aspects of the modern university experience: lumping together trigger warnings AND the banning of controversial speakers. To me this is neglectful and damaging, suggesting they themselves haven’t been put through enough rigorous conversation in the challenging of their ideals.

Must read for every parent, high school, and college studentWe know that our children must navigate the world of CRT, cancel culture, emotion vs truth, safety-ism, and snowflakes. Here is one very insightful, well-researched, and balanced book on how we got here, how to recognize it, what to do to protect free speech, and how to create a culture of respectful, civil, and diverse thought and opinion. I’m definitely going to encourage my high school and college kids to read this.

The Coddling of the American Mind  looks at the generation graduating college now and tries to see why they are so fragile emotionally. From the way, this generation of college students was raised to how schools handled shaping these young people. All of this has led to creating overprotected young adults who are taking longer to mature. The authors' intentions are to help future generations not need overprotection from society as they enter the real world and leave their family home. While kids are young they need the freedom to make mistakes and have those times used as a learning experience. Basically to sum it up let kids take risks while they're growing up. “Prepare your child for the road, not the road for your child.”

When there is a book that makes people on both sides of the political spectrum unhappy/uncomfortable I’m probably going to like it. The book could have been much shorter, however every page was filled with ideas to chew on and consider. What do i do when I disagree? Are words violent? Am I willing to give someone the benefit of the doubt or jump to worse case scenarios. Am I surrounded by people who think the same way I do, and how might that be damaging? And then how does this all apply to my children?

Okay, this book continues to stick with me. I believe everyone should walk away from this book feeling slightly offended or challenged - and it is to their betterment. The authors do not stick to an ideological side and go so far as to critique everyone. While I do agree that some of the points could be made more succinctly, the elaboration is helpful in creating more rounded out thoughts for much of the book. Can’t read or listen to it fast, but it’s worth it. I also love the applications at the end/the parenting based research and insight sprinkled though the last few chapters.

This was excellent. I listened to it on audio, but plan to buy a hard copy so I can reference it as my children go through different stages in life - or more accurately - as I go through different stages of parenting.
Breathing easier now. Essential reading mostly for those of us concerned about the future of education.
Far out this is an eye opener. 5 stars
Fascinating research combined with realistic steps forward and an optimistic vision for the future. A great example of secular thinkers who are gifted as talented exegetes of general revelation.

An interesting take, though I don't think it deserves NYT bestseller hype. Unfortunately, I think some of this book's ideas, specifically a certain negative conception of 'safetyism', could even function to work against some of the voices calling for needed changes to existing power structures by letting readers chalk legitimate calls for change up as 'safetyism.' This is one of those books where the authors are well-credentialed, articulate, Tedtalk thought leaders, and I had to remind myself not to just nod along without challenging them back. I think I agree with some of the principles in this book. I agree that we as an American culture have developed emotionally-charged attitudes towards opposing viewpoints and that can sometimes lead to unhealthy and less critical ways of thinking on both sides of political issues. I agree we need to find ways to have civil discourse on difficult moral topics between people who hold opposing viewpoints, especially on college campuses. I do think that there is a problem in the increasing use of 'us-versus-them' rhetoric. That said, I wasn't full convinced by some of the other assertions. Their commentary on 'common-humanity identity politics' as opposed to 'common-enemy identity politics' felt fair in some ways—I do think that where possible it's most effective to try to bring in a wide array of people as opposed to fomenting negativity towards a common enemy (I think that’s likely the best strategy for making change). But in politics there IS almost always a useful common enemy of a sort (perhaps not all rich straight white men, but maybe certain particular rich straight white men? or maybe better still specific immoral actions or policies and those that are making them?). In their chapter on micro-aggressions, they urge people to assume the best intentions. That's sound general advice I suppose, but there's also no reason not to raise awareness of what types of words and actions make someone feel hurt or like they don't belong. It’s still possible to do much harm even with good intentions. But it’s best for everyone if we all maintain a growth mindset, allowing for all humans to grow and learn from their missteps.They argue the words 'safety' and 'trauma' and 'violent' are being overused. 'Concept creep' they say. This assertion made me think a lot, but I came down feeling a bit differently than the authors. I think it's fair to hope that kids and adults will try to become anti-fragile, and I agree with their suggestion of cognitive behavioral therapy practices to cope instead of shielding children and ourselves from challenging viewpoints and material, but I'm still not convinced reserving these words for only physical- safety, trauma, and violence is the right approach. There are so many people whose lives are deeply affected by non-physical things, incidental or systemic, and I think these words are sometimes exactly the right way to describe those things. (Edit: Thinking and talking more about this, I realized that one negative consequence of this concept creep is that it dilutes the magnitude of certain traumas. Like if people called someone being touched briefly on the behind “rape” it starts to take something away from people who have survived rape. Maybe there are certain words that we should be more guarded about? Idk)I need to think more about callout- and cancel-culture. In my mind, there's a place for saying 'this person shouldn't be given the air time because their words/actions/viewpoints have been damaging to people in the past and may influence more damage. But this book did help me recognize how call-out culture in the university setting may be causing professors and administrators to avoid difficult, important topics on campus in order to avoid any chance of being called out. I'm sure many people feel something similar in their day to day lives. As a society we probably need to find some healthier ways of dealing with insensitivity and/or ignorance than mass public shaming and calls for dismissal. Lastly, I agree with their views that kids should probably grow up with more unstructured time and that the arms race to college admissions prep has been detrimental to children generally. But tbh what do I really know about kids?
This is soooo worth reading.

This book was recommended to me and I'm grateful for the recommendation. I actually agree with quite a few of the points the writers put forth; however, when it came to the chapter on college sports and Title IX, the writers are simply mischaracterizing what the real problem is. Equal outcomes does not mean everyone gets a rowing team - it means everyone gets a number of scholarships, and normally one team (i.e. men's football) sucks up a huge percentage of those scholarships, which means two things happen: one, women's teams are created in order to create new scholarships for women, and two, men's teams are cut in order to avoid cutting scholarships from the football team. The outcome is scholarships, not funded teams. The actual thing that is keeping the men from having their rowing team is the men's football team in this case, because the school won't ever cut anything from something that brings in that much money.So, if they are mischaracterizing the problem in that chapter, then I simply can't trust that they aren't doing the same elsewhere, including the places where I agreed. Additionally, the writers have a tendency to come up with a hypothesis that sounds real good, but then only give examples that benefit one "side" of the debate. They will later throw in terms to seemingly satisfy "both sides," but they aren't actually doing that in the analysis. Further, they go on to make recommendations to schools and colleges that go so far as to suggest curriculum that is found on their website. Most of which is what has been cut from high schools (humanities, literature, civics) in order to fund STEM education. There are mentions of the stoics and Aristotle - why not teach their writings? Surely they knew how to debate rationally, how to do so without allowing emotions to take over. Instead of a curriculum based on their writings, though, they suggest people who are founding organizations today, and I can't help but wonder if there are other motivations to those orgs.One of the two writers of the book is the leader of FIRE, an organization that has taken funding from the Koch brothers. One of the Koch's goals is "school choice," which takes money away from public education. The other point that this book fails to explore entirely is that while college campuses are definitely where students have been successful at shouting down speakers and ideas of a conservative bent, the universities as a whole are incredibly conservative institutions, and anyone working in one as faculty will tell you (especially those who are not white able-bodied men). Think of this book this way: it's a book about how to prepare for and survive plane crashes, and you will read about every plane crash you've ever heard about in the news. But you won't read about the planes that don't crash, because writing about them doesn't support the writer's hypotheses. If you don't spend any time on college campuses, and you just hear about them on the news, then yes, you will likely agree that this is what they're like. But, if you're there every day, and you spend your life with these students, you will understand just how far off this book is in its depiction of reality. Yes, some colleges have had issues with speakers being protested - some. Yes, students have jumped to conclusions without reading the entire history behind an issue or a case - I'm shocked, really. But this is hardly the first time in American history that college students have done things that made the news. I have had only 1-2 students in the five years I've been a professor actually be what the writers call too "fragile" to handle the material. They're actually quite strong and much of their desire for "safety" is due to having gone through active shooter drills their whole lives or a greater awareness of sexual assault than we had (as well as experience of it), AND out of a great deal of empathy for each other. It's not all about helicopter parenting and over-testing. Some of it is a genuine desire to change the world.
