But it is not a good idea to start by assuming the worst about people and reading their actions as uncharitably as possible. This is the distortion known as mind reading; if done habitually and negatively, it is likely to lead to despair, anxiety, and a network of damaged relationships." (40-1, emphasis theirs)One of the pitfalls of the information age is that we suddenly think we’re so damned smart, that we can understand other people better than they understand themselves. We read books and articles that purport to teach us how to detect “unconscious bias,” and gobble up partisan podcasts that so keenly articulate the assumed stances of our political and cultural opponents that we don’t feel the need to actually engage with them. I am just as guilty of this as most people, but I’m trying hard to break the habit, as should all Americans.We can start with an enthusiastic revival of the principle of charity, and with following Lukianoff and Haidt’s rules for productive disagreement:"––Frame it as a debate, rather than a conflict.––Argue as if you’re right, but listen as if you’re wrong (and be willing to change your mind).––Make the most respectful interpretation of the other person’s perspective.––Acknowledge where you agree with your critics and what you’ve learned from them." (240)Lukianoff and Haidt have offered up a terrific text that carries on the long American tradition of cultural critique; they clearly love America and want it to live up to its promise. Probably the best quote in the whole book is lifted from an interview with Van Jones, one of my political heroes:"I don’t want you to be safe ideologically. I don’t want you to be safe emotionally. I want you to be strong. That’s different. I’m not going to pave the jungle for you. Put on some boots, and learn how to deal with adversity. I’m not going to take all the weights out of the gym; that’s the whole point of the gym. This is the gym." (97)Fellow American, whoever you are, wherever you are: I’m hitting the gym. Want to join me?This review was originally published on my blog, words&dirt.

The Rad-- Found Part I (three bad ideas) and Part IV chapter 12 (wiser kids) thought-provoking and worth a read-through. The 2 page CBT appendix on species of distorted thinking would be useful to photocopy and reflect on periodically to stay out of the doldrums regardless of what generation you belong to. The Meh-- I'm skeptical about the trope of claiming the younger generation(s) have been mis-parented and are moving themselves and our collective culture off-track as it seems like I've stumbled upon similar criticisms lobbed at Boomers, Gen X, and Millenials in prior years... I guess it is alarmist enough that you could slap a fire engine red cover on it and expect to sell a decent volume of books? I'm unsure about the claim that the atmosphere at universities changed dramatically starting around 2012 (Part II) or the comprehensiveness of the list of drivers for this change (Part III). Claiming recent political events are as emotionally powerful as any since the late 1960's and have galvanized a generation to fight for social change seems like it might be a bit of an over-reach... Sure, POTUS45 is a departure, but really? In the fullness of time, will we think what we are seeing now is on par with MLK, et al? But the quest for justice hypothesis aside, I did find myself flashing back to a 43 min Youtube of Jordan Peterson on a tear about Postmodernism and Cultural Marxism where he raised a lot of similar criticisms about campus culture that left me wondering if something has changed about the social climate in universities since I graduated.

I really appreciated that this was such a thoughtful, measured look at campus free speech debates rather than being filled with the hysterical judgment that so often encompasses discussions of this issue. It’s also about much more than campus call-out culture, going into the parenting techniques and university policies that not only make young people weaker intellectually and emotionally but increase rates of anxiety, depression, self-harm, and suicide. This was the part of the book that struck me most: Identity politics that creates an us-vs.-them, good-vs.-evil mentality — as opposed to identity politics that creates a common-humanity mentality — is linked to negative physical outcomes in those who practice it. The first half of the book is very compelling; the next quarter is interesting; and the last quarter consists of recommendations on how to move forward. The book quotes Pauli Murray, a black and queer Episocopal priest and civil rights activist who, in 1965, at the age of 55, earned a degree from Yale Law School: “When my brothers try to draw a circle to exclude me, I shall draw a larger circle to include them.” Words to live by. Grade: A-

I’m not entirely sure there is a book of this caliber, on this topic, out in the market of current events/political/psychology non-fiction. Haidt, as usual, has contributed to a book that is at once gracious and direct, to the heart of the issue: our social constructionism ideology is making our kids and society more fragile, thus (if you take the metaphor a bit further) more susceptible to diseases, of which, we used to be immune. It’s not every day that that two very prominent liberals, who have no record of voting for a single Republican candidate, write the most interesting and challenging book on the subject of free expression, antifragility, and social psychology that has come around to enthrall conservatives and liberals alike, in many years. Perhaps they are the once and future liberals we have always hoped would be amongst the “loyal opposition,” but as the cultural conversation shifts to a more antagonistic brand of scapegoating and “othering,” we need to stick together, for the health of the country and the virtue of our communities, individually and as a whole. The three great untruths in the first part of the book are worth the entire price. I’m going to use it, as I have with Haidt’s other books, to engage with my community to seek truth and justice in the (post)modern age of groundless identity.

I found a lot of the principles and stories in this book very helpful and good for discussion. The main idea is “Prepare the child for the road, not the road for the child.” It shows us how over-protective parenting (among other things) led to cancel culture. Specifically, it was helpful to have instances of cancel culture broken down to see why they resulted from illogical thinking, such as catastrophizing and labeling. And the parenting tips were very helpful, such as prioritizing free play in younger kids and encouraging debate and responsibility in older kids.However, from a Christian point of view, there were a few things that I would think about differently. For instance the authors highly recommend CBT and mindfulness as remedies for anxiety and depression, but I would obviously add prayer and reading the Word as ways to help us identify and counteract unhelpful thoughts. Also even the main point “Prepare the child for the road”—I agree with this from a biblical perspective, since we ask the Holy Spirit to guide us and give us strength. However, we are also called to pray and trust the Lord to intervene in our circumstances too, aka preparing the road.

Very well done. I would call it required reading if I were into requiring stuff of people I'm not related to. Haidt and Lukianoff, both excellent writers on their own, expanded their 2016 Atlantic article of the same title into a book length meditation on a number of things-- properly summed up: facts > feelings. They bring together research in psychology, internet culture, child-rearing and others to present a picture of the currently disenchanted generation of young people for whom "safety" is all encompassing. It's both very frightening (lose your livelihood because your face accidentally did a thing because you zoned out during a meeting and microaggressed someone in Generation Safe Space) and hopeful-- learning more about social media and device use can help people help their children become, in the words of Nicholas Nassim Taleb "antifragile." Great, great stuff. And a shout-out to Lenore Skenazy, woo!

“Prepare the child for the road, not the road for the child.”A must-read for every parent, teacher, college administrator, or really anyone who interacts with kids and young adults. With mental illness on the rise for kids/teens, peoples’ inability to tolerate other perspectives, and the decrease of free play + face-to-face social interaction, it only makes sense that we need to dramatically alter the way we grapple with what we consider “safety.” I also loved their points about diversity - is a campus really diverse if we don’t allow diverse points of view and differing thought? I was impressed with their ability to bring in ample amounts of research and evidence to support their points. I also enjoyed the “In Sum” part of each chapter, and the practical tips at the end (especially as a parent of an adventure-seeking toddler). Four stars only because it got a little long towards the end, some points were repetitive.

This is a thought-provoking book. While it may not be the end-all guide for how and why the younger people in our society sometimes behave (positively and negatively) the way they do, it does provide an alternative viewpoint and thought path to seeing things through their eyes.If you are interested in a different, albeit more in-depth viewpoint, into the mind of today's youth, this is an informative read. It gives you things to look for and ideas as to why people react the way they do as well as tips for helping kids that are growing up in the turbulent atmosphere.This is the first book/study that I have read on this subject. Definitely something to think about and a good conversation starter for engaging with parents, educators, children, or just about anyone interested in understanding today's atmosphere.

Lukianoff and Haidt's The Coddling of the American Mind will be viewed as one of the most insightful and salient commentaries on the post-2010 trends in youth (10-30 years of age) psychology. The authors describe the ongoing evolution of problematic mental heuristics (i.e. safetyism) that plague our the minds of many young people in society. These mental traps propagate misery and acrimony, erecting barriers to productive conversations and individual maturation/flourishing. It makes for an engaging and thought-provoking read.Unfortunately, more people have not read this book (or the article that previewed it by the same authors) as it seems more and more people have minds governed by problematic, overly simplistic thinking (the three Great Untruths: fragility, emotional reasoning, and us vs them thinking). The authors' balanced and thoughtful warning should be heeded.

“A culture that allows the concept of “safety” to creep so far that it equates emotional discomfort with physical danger is a culture that encourages people to systematically protect one another from the very experiences embedded in daily life that they need in order to become strong and healthy.”My generation is full of anxiety and entitlement that life should be a certain way. While I don't necessarily agree with the solutions this book offers that are based in psychology and evolution, I think the observations and arguments are worth noting.Though I know this world to be cursed with sin and the only real answer to many of these problems is found through the saving work of Jesus Christ, the author offers some valuable insights to consider as we think about our present world.

Lukianoff and Haidt do a fantastic job at eloquently explaining the recent phenomena that we have been witnessing in today's culture. Rather than condemning the oversensitivity on college campus on ideological grounds, Lukianoff and Haidt provide evidence as to why this type of mentality is not conducive to our well-being. Haidt and Lukianoff defend this position by honestly representing the opposition and digging deep in attempting to diagnose the genesis of this new phenomenon. It's a must-read for anyone who is about to step foot on campus for the next few years of their lives as it presents a challenging argument as to why they should reevaluate the claims that has been spewed consistently by the oversensitive brigade who think they are acting in the best interest of society.

The authors consider the three great untruths: what doesn’t kill you makes you weaker, trust your feelings, us versus them. And they show how through encouraging safety-ism, which encourages cognitive distortions characteristic of these untruths, college campuses (as well as parents) are causing iGen-ers to suffer from a decline in mental health. Their solutions fall along the lines of personal, parenting, and campus changes in thinking and policy. Their solutions are generated from statistical research and cognitive behavior therapy, which in my view is an intuitively sound way to go about counseling sharing similarities with the nouthetic counseling I learned in seminary.

Can’t recommend this book enough. I think the authors effectively explain the rising hostility going on in America today and ways to alleviate it. The book also touches on many self help and parenting topics that I found useful. I will definitely be reading this again in the future and referencing it in discussions with friends and family.

I found this book pretty frustrating and I imagine some of this is from the editor(s) in addition to the authors. There was a lot that seemed inflammatory even though the underlying ideas, especially highlighted at the end, are moderate. The authors would often make an extreme statement and then walk it back, or talk about overreactions and then acknowledge that there have been times when extreme reactions were called for. It was hard to shake the feeling that this wasn't just another book harkening back to the "good old days." It's a shame, because overall I agree with them in a lot of places, especially about the benefits of CBT.

This book was excellent! The authors have clearly done their research on the changes on college campuses since 2013 (such as students actually wanting to limit freedom of speech), and their theories on why this has happened. They also offer suggestions to how to move forward and what parents and college administrators can do to help students become "anti-fragile" and provide them with the coping mechanisms needed to survive in difficult or uncomfortable situations.10/10 would recommend. There are a lot of statistics listed throughout the book, but they are used in a ways that aren't boring or distracting from their overall argument. Very well written!

#20BooksOfSummerFinished: 23.06.2019Genre:  non-fictionRating: A++++++Conclusion:University campuses have changed since my daysiGen's are less prepared for the challenges, why? Political quirk: most white Americans vote Republican...except those born after 1981 and b/t 1950-1954 (...me)...again, why?#MustRead for all who want to be prepared for the coming2020 election year....college is building our future leaders.and especially parents with children going to or presently in college.
My Thoughts

I knew just a few chapters in that this book was bad; I didn’t realize just how bad it was until I forced myself to go on.I initially selected it thinking it might provide thoughtful insights and challenge some of my own personal and professional viewpoints. I clearly gave the authors far too much credit.Instead, I slogged through irresponsible/ignorant treatment of #foodallergies & ill-informed libertarian opinions masquerading as intelligent thought/fact.I’ve read 150+ books in 2019 so far; this is the worst. It’s not even close. The authors should be embarrassed by just how bad this book is. In a word... trash.

EVERYONE SHOULD READ THIS BOOK.If you wonder where the "snowflake" mindset originated and how fragility invaded the free thinking of our universities, this book answers those questions.This book is incredibly researched, and authors' political bias (while purposely revealed in a later chapter) is completely removed. They point fingers of blame in all directions, offering solutions at the conclusion.One of the most thought-provoking books I've ever read, and the best I've read in a really, really long time.I can't recommend it enough. Read it. Reread it. Then implement it. It could change our society and our ability to express alternate viewpoints forever.

3.5/5 stars I agreed with the premise of this book before picking it up, and for that reason it was not the most exciting book for me. I found The Righteous Mind so much more interesting. Having said that, this book had a ton of research and data to back everything up and makes a great case that we are destroying a generation of children in the name of cancel culture, safetyism, and not understanding the concept of antifragility. This was a quick read, and an important one. My parenting style (and that of my parents) has a healthy dose of free-range in it, and now I'm glad to have some scientists backing me up.

such an eye-opening, thoughtful, well-written read. as a current college student, extremely applicable to my situation and the situation of others whom i know on their respective campuses. i’m left with a lot of whirling thoughts about how to combat safetyism and the three great untruths in my own mind, how to — as an individual and as a member of a college community — display my commitment to the preservation of open dialogic debate and the protection of free speech, and how to move forward from here. i definitely don’t have all of the answers, but this book has offered a very helpful framework for navigating current campus climates, and i will definitely be revisiting it.

A thorough look into possible causes of modern outrage culture and why these views are especially evident on college campuses today. It gives insight into how social media, over cautious parenting, and common thought distortions can “coddle” children while developing and prevent them from becoming stable adults. It is very positive - the book appeals to common humanity and provides many tips on moving forward, especially for new parents. Short, easy read, lots of good advice for anyone, would recommend.

The intended audience for this book are parents (which I am not) and those in higher education (which I am). Published in 2018, it is strikingly prescient for 2021. It pushes back against safetyism and an us versus them mentality and encourages us to foster healthy debate and learn how to deal with uncomfortable ideas and adversity. I found it a must-read for all in higher education.It was originally an op-ed in The Atlantic, expanded into a book. Unfortunately, it does still read as an op-ed to me. I found myself wishing for a bit more data.

An important analysis of the age, I think. An examination of the "3 Great Untruths" currently reshaping American colleges, the aspects of modern parenting and culture that gave the 3 Great Untruths currency, and guidance for what to do about them. Not unlike my response to reading Ben Sasse's The Vanishing American Adult, I was troubled by the cultural trends and challenged to adjust aspects of how I parent.

I agree with a lot of what was said but this is definitely "lighter" nonfiction in the sense that it had less statistics and history than I think the subject matter warranted. There was plenty of interesting narration and psychological insights, but I think a stronger case could've been made. Still giving it 4 stars as it would serve as a good eye-opener for people unfamiliar with the current state of Western youths and academia.

If you find yourself perplexed about Black Lives Matters protests, the rejection of Critical Race Theory training by President Trump, and the intermittent craziness on university campuses, this book is a sensible starting place to understand some of the major trends happening today. These two authors take a centrist approach in tracing the origins of these movements and provide plenty of stories and footnotes to bolster their case.

I’d give this five stars if this was more comprehensive versus focusing on a few high profile examples while portraying them as the norm and indicative of the now instead of the future normal. I think this book barely scratched the surface of what could be a multi-volume analysis and discussion of the attacks on education, civil discourse and how to address controversial topics in modern scholastic environments.

Almost gave this five stars. Still might change my mind. Working with college students, this book rang true on many levels. I have seen firsthand the advent of safetyism and the shift from justice to social justice. I actually yelled out loud at one part of this book because I agreed so wholeheartedly.My favorite quote: “Prepare the child for the road, not the road for the child.”A good companion read: “The Conservative Heart” by Arthur Brooks.

universities have become averse to debate, free speech is subordinated to everyone's comfort, and safetyism is transforming education into an ideology camp. haidt explores the reasons for this, from helicopter parenting to the rise of administrative bureaucracies in universities. really frustrating to read about college students' reactions to simply being exposed to opposing viewpoints. they are extremely weak and sadly coddled.

I expected more from this book, but conflating rape culture (authors view is that it doesn't exist) with fragility (vs antifragility, with loose borrowings from Taleb) and immunization is a spectacular stretch. I quit at 10% of the books as views and logic close to Jordan Peterson are of no interest to me.The premise of the book is good, the interpretations, examples and logic, fail.

i do not agree with all of the authors’ conclusions and this book is not perfect, but whew, this has to be one of the most important issues of our day. i particularly appreciated their recommendations on how to raise children to be thoughtful, open-minded critical thinkers who intentionally seek out nuance and complexity and are not afraid of earnest debate.

The author completely overlooks his own privilege, disregards faults of his own generations, and goes on to make false generalizations about Gen Z (e.g. that they’re fragile) from a narrow minded white-cis-hetero lens. It’s basically narrow mindedness packaged as “academic” analysis or whatever. No thanks.
Good interview with the author on KQED Forum: Social Psychologist Jon Haidt on ‘The Coddling Of The American Mind’.

Ya'll have got to read this book. Two liberalish writers delve into the nonsense we're seeing on college campuses (trigger warnings and the like) and offer some surprising insight and suggest the way out.

Сборная солянка советов по решению проблем современного американского социального дискурса. Еще и немножко когнитивно поведенческой терапии и осознанности. Разумные доводы, но слишком привязанные к текущему моменту.

A timely book as we’ve raised up an ultra-sensitive generation incapable of navigating adulthood. Unnecessary overprotection has kept them from establishing the necessary attribute of resiliency making everything in life just too hard to deal with...

If I could have given this two and a half stars, I would have. The authors clearly had an ax to grind, using anecdotal evidence to support their political purpose instead of actual research based data.

Un libro instrumental acerca de la ola de intolerancia e infantilismo en el boicot de debates en las universidades. Recoge con detalle buena parte de los incidentes y es recomendable sobre todo para académicos, continúa el magnífico "La mente de los justos" de Haidt.

I really loved this book! It helped me understand the uniqueness of Gen Z. It is a very academic read so it can be dry at times but very interesting. This gave me good perspective on how I would like to parent. I would recommend this book to anyone who plans on working with this generation.

I recommend this to any educator but especially to high school teachers and university professors. I also recommend it to anyone who is interested in current issues, sociology, history, neurology, cognitive behavioral therapy, and/or learning. I really enjoyed the read.

This is pretty narrow minded book. As a recent college graduate, I guess this author doesn't really understand what iGen or young generation are walking through. I was disappointed with this high rating too.

People are anti-fragile: we are made better by hardship, and we atrophy in the absence of it. Especially mentally, emotionally, socially.This is a diagnosis of the United States’ illness of “safetyism” that provides space for the type of critique and breadth of conversation that we all need.
You should read it, especially if you're a parent.
I gave this more time than it deserved before finally abandoning it, right about to 117th mention of the term "witch hunt".
One of the best books I've ever read. Should be required for all parents
I think this book should be required reading for everyone in higher ed, faculty, staff, and students.
Excelente análisis de la iGen y de los crecientes problemas con la libertad de expresión. Creo que es un libro que todo el mundo debiera leer para, al menos, discutir si no están de acuerdo.
Great book, especially good for parents.
Incredibly eye-opening and necessary, given the times we live in. In a perfect world, this book would make its way into the lives of every prospective parent and every prospective college student.
Rating 3.5 StarsHmm...RTC
Prepare the child for the road, not the road for the child. Great book to read as I start a job in Higher Ed. Much to consider.
Said the words “oh my gosh” out loud probably about 14 times while listening to this book

Saftig som fan, sätter fingret rakt på G-punkten så det kittlar till. Ytterligare en av flera böcker som skildrar vår samtid och generations särdrag avseende samtalsklimat, vad som verkar vara ökande polarisering mellan ideologiska läger och en växande psykisk ohälsa hos vår generation. Diverse kausala faktorer diskuteras flitigt i boken (sociala medier (samt tillgång till internet hela ens liv), ökat inslag av "safetyism" både hos föräldraskap och vid institutioner och arbetsplatser etc etc). Boken finner sin nyans perfekt skildrad i dess underrubrik: How Good Intentions and Bad Ideas Are Setting Up a Generation for Failure. Jag tar dock bokens centrala poänger för att spä på mina svart-vita uppfattningar om världen och nedan följer, i sedvanlig ordning, ett raljerande om ett knippe återkommande ämnen/begrepp i mina "reviews".  Det finns tre centrala "Bad Ideas" som mynnar ut och förkroppsligas av diverse faktorer och fenomen, dessa tre är: - The Untruth of Fragility: What Doesn't Kill You Makes You Weaker.Idén om att barn och vuxna är sköra varelser som skall behandlas lika varsamt som fint porslin. Begrepp som safetyism och fenomen som safe spaces etc diskuteras här (och varför det strider mot idéer centrala inom KBT, även nämnt nedan). Två ytterst tillfredställande begrepp presenteras här, ett i synnerhet kopplat till denna "osanning" och ett som skildrar fenomen överlag genom hela boken i vår samtid idag: Antifragility resp. Concept creep. Förstnämnda beskriver hur människors psyke (och barn som små varelser) är snarare som system likt våra ben och immunförsvar: Det måste utsättas för skit för att bygga upp resistans. Går vi runt med bomullstussar hela livet blir endast ömtåliga i längden (finns mycket forskning som visar på barn som inte för lära sig uppleva och hantera sina känslor på egen hand i ung ålder blir sedan helt emotionellt överkörd av alla jävla känslor som slår till när hormoner och pubertetslivet kommer i full skinka. Finns inga som helst copingstrategier). Ett väldigt lökigt, men bra, citat från boken är "Prepare the Child for the road, not the road for the child". Släpp alla jävla utopiska tankar om att inget barn ska göra sig illa eller att ingen ska vara ensam; livet är för jävligt, orättvist och ett enda lidande. Barnet behöver guidas till att skaffa en inre kompass för att ta sig igenom det, så att det inte blir en liten self-righteous "Hampstead Cunt" som blir "moral dependent" av en tredje aktör (ex. en skitunge i skolan som springer utan att blinka till fröken så fort minsta lilla händer utan att ens försöka lösa det direkt med ens kamrat. Dessa är de, som boken argumenterar (mer min tolkning) sedan kommer till universitetscampus och arbetsmarkanden och börjar kräva sina rättigheter (utan ansvar) och får moralpanik så fort någon tycker annorlunda än en (inte nog på flera campus i USA där man inom Humaniora blir direkt uppmande av professorer (*** märkligt nog av samma ideologisk hållning) att skrika ner meningsmotståndare istället för att engagera sig i ett meningsfullt utbyta av åsikter och information. Denna "osanning" kopplar an till concept creep, som nämnt långt ovan, där begrepp har tillåts tappa sina ursprungliga, sanna, semantiska innebörd. Hot och Våld är sådande begrepp där våld har gått från att vara enbart av ett fysiskt fenomen till att det nu kan vara verbalt (och det i sin tur bedöms utifrån subjektiva och relativistiska ramverk (som passar narrativet)) vilket - återigen - är helt absurt om man sedan tar en titt på centrala idéer inom KBT (boken lägger ut detta klart och tydligt). Finns även andra begrepp som har tappat sin mening och blir därmed värdelösa samt korrumperade av dess urvattnade definition (och har blivit så för att vissa teoretiska ramverk ska kunna överleva och inte minst expandera sin "förklaringskraft" på saker som "strukturella" fenomen i samhället (dvs vad Pluckrose och Lindsay perfekt benämner som "Theory"). - The Untruth of Emotional Reasoning: Always Trust Your Feelings. Haidt kommer in här med sin bakgrund i moralpsykologi och metaforen kring "The (rational) rider and the (social intuitive (irrational)) elephant)" - Den klassiska! Hänvisar till The Righteous mind och The Happiness Hypothesis för att sätta tänderna i vad metaforen innebär. I kort handlar invändingen mot dagens lögn att vända sig till sina egna inre känslor för visdom och vägledning att moralfilsofisk och kunskapsteoretisk subjektivism är doomed to fail om man vill bygga sammanhållande, positiva och växande samhällen (surprise, surprise!). De gör även en sjukt sexig redovisning över hur en sådan förhållning till världen strider mot grundläggande principer i KBT. - The Untruth of Us versus Them: Life Is a Battle Betweeen Good People and Evil People. Solz. odödliga citat om att "the line between good and evil cuts through the heart of every man" (Bah, ish typ så) och en skön distinktion mellan positiv, universell inkluderande identitetspolitik (ex. MLK) och negativ, exkluderande, polariserande, primitiv, vedervärdig, smutsig, moraliskt underlägsen, tragisk identitespolitik (tänk frön från pomo via 90-talets shenanigans inom akademin och dess mobiliserande under 2010-talet). Återigen kopplas detta an till varför det hamnar i kontrast till KBT. Mycket annat bra tas upp och det Jonathan Haidt ska hållas för (i linje med Pinker) är hans fläckfria nyanserade resonemang vars primära mål är att beskriva ett problem i samtida västvärlden och sedan erbjuda lösningar som ligger i allas intresse att de implementeras. Om någon senare vän på Goodreads har lyckats ta sig ned hit kan det vara vart att nämna att mina reviews är 95% raljerande om 3-4 begrepp på sin höjd och oftast avviker kraftigt från vad boken faktiskt skriver om. Men boken är bra och högst aktuell: 5+

Was almost deterred by the reviews saying this should have stayed an essay -- I've been burned too many times by books trying to make their wordcounts -- but I'm glad I wasn't and honestly, I think this is one of the most important books I've read in a while. The thesis is that the free speech incidents on campuses of the last ten years are not only alarming in and of themselves but that they are symptomatic of a much deeper and more troubling cultural shift towards "safetyism" which could have - and arguably already has had - far-reaching, deleterious consequences for America and the ascendant generation. By the end of the book, I'm fully convinced . I've only recently reckoned with my own "safetyist" tendencies. I was a sensitive kid, and in life I've had a tendency to practice avoidant behavior -- to avoid uncomfortable situations rather than confronting them and getting the benefit of learning from them. I didn't realize I was doing it, but in retrospect - having had some recent personal setbacks, and some CBT-esque therapy as a consequence - it's clear that I was, and that that behavior impeded me from making the kinds of good, hard-wearing decisions that would have improved my long-term outcomes.I think we ought heed the warnings of these academics closely, because after all, they are on the "frontlines" of this particular battleground. ie. They are the ones responsible for training the next generation and preparing them for the "real world". By their reports, younger students are engaging in alarming frequency in the kinds of cognitive distortions thoroughly taxonomized by the psychological literature on CBT - catastrophization, overgeneralization, emotional reasoning, etc. - which should be avoided in everyday life, much less in places that are meant to be bastions of free thought and free discourse.The authors stop shy of offering an out-and-out denunciation of the higher education system in America -- they are academics after all -- but increasingly I'm finding it necessary. The higher education system has become one of those rare exemptions, like the Church, that, because of some ambiguous but mutually-agreed-upon moral prerogative, is not subject to the kinds of oversight that other businesses are subject to. But make no mistake that higher education is a business. And because so many employers in America steadfastly refuse to consider uncredentialed applicants - or because we have no alternative means of assessing general competency - higher education is able to operate almost like a cartel. Any young person MUST if they have any hope of a bright economic future get an undergraduate degree. (How is this different from a Taxi medallion in NYC?) And higher education institutions are invested not so much in giving you a good education, as they are in convincing you that the degree is a sound investment. Inherent in this is the notion that the opportunity cost of 4 years of life and huge amounts of incurred debt is worth the loss of income or on-the-job training one would otherwise receive.It remains true (if only for reasons of cultural inertia) that the undegraduate degree is a sound investment (and assuredly so for the top 50 or so schools). But in the process of rendering this argument the universities are and have been inculcating the younger generations (including my own) with notions that are dangerous at best -- for example that learning is inherently valuable (is it? even when that learning has no bearing whatsoever on one's ultimate occupation?); that thinking or writing or talking is as good as, or equal to, effectual action (is it? can you think food into existence? can you think shelter into existence?); that the thinking person's life is the highest possible aspiration (and what if you need to work to live?). I would argue that the prerogative of education is not to promote scholarship per se but to empower the individual -- and that some of these notions are entirely counterproductive to those aims. This is not post-World-War-II America anymore. We are not experiencing a glut of opportunity or overabundance of resources. Many of us (especially those of us with student loans, although I'm lucky enough not to be in that camp) do IN FACT have to work. But it doesn't take four years of education to learn to be an electrician or a plumber, so the universities push humanities.I digress. (And for what it's worth, I'm extremely grateful for my own education and miss college like heck). If any one thing is to blame for the over-sensitivity of Gen Z, it is social media, and the authors make that point as well. The perpetrators of the social media takeover are at least witting (the quote from Sean Parker is especially damning, though I don't have it to hand), and they make better villains. And ironically, because they are by and large young (Millenials at the oldest) the founders of these social media superpowers are likelier allies to Gen Z'ers, even despite their millions and billions of personal net worth. Because the thing is -- and this is what really worries me -- this is seeming more and more like some kind of inter-generational conflict. That young people, who are much more savvy on the platforms that seem to matter most, are increasingly unwilling to heed the warnings or advice of the older generations. That "life experience" is being de-platformed in favor of... I don't know what. Memes? It just seems like a bad idea. It just seems like a bad idea to reshuffle the social order in that way. Because some things, you just don't understand EXCEPT by life experience. The moderation that comes with age, is a good thing. And I say that as an insufferably stubborn 34-year-old who's made it his life mission not to listen to anyone's advice.Anyway. It's a good book.

It’s funny, I accept this work as the masterful unveiling of a new exhibit, recently cataloged by social scientists Haidt and Lukianoff, and forget that I’m the prop. I’m the college student, the Gen Zer, up for discussion. And in that light, this meta-analysis of datasets seems a little strange, like it’s as easy as attributing the problems of my generation to not getting to play outdoors and as easily solved as self-administered CBT. Partly because of their training as psychologists (or at least Haidt’s), the moral diagnosis of the book is closet utilitarianism: it’s very effects focused, to the point of admitting that it won’t deal with the bigger “why” or moral ramifications raised by the questions. So the question is just “what works?” and the criteria for an “untruth” laid out in the introduction is that an idea contradicts wisdom literature, modern psychological research on flourishing, and harms those who embrace it. These are very hastily sketched out and never justified. Examples from wisdom literature seem to be chosen willy-nilly, whether from Boethius or Solzhenitsyn. Flourishing is never defined, nor is the authors’ own definition of harm (although they do argue strongly against the concept creep which has rendered harm so hard to define). This vagueness is reflected by the ending, which is, to be frank, a little silly: the goal is to be “stronger, richer, more virtuous, and safer” (for what? From what? To what end?). The big ideas are that we should promote psychological strength through controlled exposure to adversity rather than protecting against it wholesale (as with peanut allergens in the 90s), allow kids to play unsupervised a little more, and step back from tribalistic identity politics, preferring instead a common humanity model. If this feels a little scattered, it’s because the authors are trying to unify various threads around the theme of “emotional and mental unpreparedness” exhibited by young adults as they go to college. They work backwards from case studies like Evergreen College’s riots and the race-based fervor at Claremont McKenna college to prove that something is wrong, and college students are disfavoring free speech in order to create ideological homogeneity and safety. But the authors do a masterful job of ducking and weaving around the question of where morality takes us (aside for the fact that it “binds and blinds”) so it’s a little jarring for them to speak so resoundingly on behalf of truth as the mission of a university. They don’t address per se the problem of subjectivity, scientific turmoil, or literary criticism that may have contributed to universities eschewing this mission. I have a little bit of issue with the authors’ pop-level reading and presentation of philosophy, particularly the portrayal of Boethius’ dialogues with Lady Philosophy as an exercise in CBT (um, what?). Bits and pieces of philosophers are thrown in (like Aristotle, for instance) as citations to wisdom literature, but the benefit of such a tradition is never explained or defended, nor is the choice of certain authors as representative. There’s a crucial element missing of the religious story interwoven with morality, and how this question of absolute truth or doctrine might intersect not just with vaguely great thinkers of some vague canon, but with specific, historical understandings of morality rooted in God and the church. Anyway, the historical sections seem fairly cursory and scanty. All that said, I think this book might be helpful in peeling back some blinders to its intended audience (presumably middle-class parents and liberal intellectuals in the elite institutions it refers to). Some of its advice may be more helpful or relevant than others, since the advice bullet points seem somewhat casually collected. It’s true that higher education seems to be facing a crisis related to maladaptive logical thinking and severe groupthink/in-group bias. How students want to be regulated is just as much of a question as how they are regulated, and the question of autonomy versus standards of excellence or control seems to surface repeatedly. All that to say, mob rule in a university is a terrible idea, and so is knowledge through violence, or redefinition of concepts to expand the concept of violence. And (as poorly explained as their idea of truth was) I found this quote particularly relevant and worth repeating: “The truth is powerful, yet the process by which we arrive at truth is easily corrupted by the desires of the seekers and the social dynamics of the community.”

This was such an interesting and insightful read!We live in an age in which the new generation (iGen) looks and thinks quite differently to their parents and grandparents generations. Sometimes it can be confusing to try to make sense of things such as cancel culture, the seeming fragility of youth (sometimes pejoratively called ‘snowflake culture’), safe spaces & safetyism and how many words like ‘harm’ & ‘trauma’ have seemed to change both in usage and meaning. It can seem like this all came up out of nowhere all of a sudden. However, every ideology and cultural movement has its roots which are important to understand. This is where this book offers helpful explanations to help show the roots and understand the thought processes behind these cultural trends.The authors frame the discussion within the framework of the search for wisdom - which is really what is needed to combat a lot of the underlying issues this generation faces. They draw on several sources of wisdom - from traditional religions and philosophy - to help make their case.The book’s premise hinges on what they call the Three Great Untruths:1. The Untruth of Fragility: What doesn’t kill you makes you weaker2. The Untruth of Emotional Reasoning: Always trust your feelings3. The Untruth of Us Versus Them: Life is a battle between good people and evil peopleThey use these 3 Great Untruths to help diagnose the problems endemic to and facing the current generation.The book is divided up into four main parts:1. Explaining the bad ideas of the great untruths2. Examples of the untruths in action3. How did we get here - 6 factors which contributed to the current situation4. Wising up - some of the authors’ recommendations for building wiser kids, universities and societies.Overall, I thought the book did a great job of diagnosing the problems and illustrating their points well. There is enough data to make their case compelling and thorough, yet not too much to make it feel like reading a statistics textbook. Some of their stories which were chosen to illustrate some of the untruths in action seemed to be pretty extreme - however, it does a good job of illustrating the end of these bad ideas. Sometimes, the incidents (though true stories) seemed too unbelievable to think that people can believe and think in those ways. But once one understands the ideologies behind - it helps one understand why. You may find (as I did) several moments saying “oh, that’s why that is so!”I really liked the framing of the conversation in terms of the search for wisdom - as that is really what is needed to combat this issues. I really liked the quote they used about parents encouraging their children to not be like candles which wind can extinguish but rather like a fire that is energized by the wind as they face the rigours of the real world. “You want to be the fire and wish for the wind.” Also, “prepare the child for the road not the road for the child.” The authors also offered helpful advice from Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) as remedies to the three untruths. However, though the authors drew from other religious and philosophical traditions, there was not much insight offered from Christianity (which was noticeably absent to me). Christianity’s wisdom literature in the bible and its tradition of theology has much to say on these topics. But I also don’t expect the authors (who seem to come at it from a secular psychological and sociological perspective) to employ robust Christian theology. I think though, that a theologian could easily take some of their insights to help inform how they may be able to speak to these issues in our culture.Overall, this was a very worthwhile read - especially for someone trying to understand better our cultural moment and some of the issues facing iGen and being propagated everywhere around us through media, pop-psychology and academic institutions. The authors’ insights are invaluable, and they offer some helpful advice in the closing chapters for some practical steps which can be taken. However, I think that the solutions offered are a good start but not a complete remedy. I think that church leaders and Christians will find this a thought-provoking book that will help them consider how to meaningfully and strategically engage the culture today.Highly recommended read!

When I was a kid I loved video games. I internalized a lot of myself and video games and books appealed to that internalized life because internalized adventures are safer, easier, and less constrained by reality. My Mom's sensibilities as a 3rd grade teacher allowed for unlimited book reading but excessive video games were frowned upon in my household. The older I got my dad started telling me stories about the adventures he would go on when he was my age, climbing trees in the local orange grove, riding bikes, etc. One day he said, "When I was your age my friends and I would go find coyote dens and throw rocks at the sleeping coyotes," to which I responded, "Do you want me to throw rocks at coyotes?" and he replied with a parental party line, "not necessarily..." A day came when he told me he wanted to go on a bike ride with me and I started following him down a path I had been down many times on my bike. He took me on a turn off the normal safe Southern Orange County Government Maintained Biking Trail down an uneven dirt path that eventually led into an enormous field of wildflowers. At the edge of this field was a cliff so steep that falling would certainly imply death. Or at least that was my perspective as a kid, in retrospect it was about a 20-30 foot drop. A tall tree sat at the edge of the cliff and some local hooligans had drilled 2x4s into the side of the tree and tied a rope with a knot at the bottom from the top branch over the cliff. My Dad casually grabbed the rope, ran as fast as he could, and swung himself over the cliff, my mouth agape. He did it a few more times before looking at me, as if inviting me to join him. I gave a resounding but guilty shake of my head no, and he did not pressure me into giving it a shot. This was a solid parenting decision at the time because I certainly did not have the upper body strength to hold onto a swinging rope at the time and there was probably a 50% chance of failure. That day marked a turning point in my life of getting outside of wandering the world with my friends. We made it a regular habit of meeting up on our bikes to find childhood adventures that I look back as my favorite moments growing up, running through forests, finding rivers and jumping from rock to rock upstream, and catching frogs with my best friends. I have gone back looking for the field of wild flowers that felt like entering a competently new beautiful world, but it has long since been paved with concrete and someones home has been planted there now. I was reminiscing with my Dad about that trip and he told me that he didn't see a sense of adventure in me and wanted to instill that in my in my childhood. In my estimation, my sense of adventure lay under the surface where it didn't belong and bringing it out is one of the reasons that have absolutely no struggle with anything remotely similar to an anxiety disorder today, which may put me in the minority of my peers. As it turns out, according to the research in this book, excessive screen time has created an epidemic of anxiety and depression for an entire generation. The "anti-woke culture" sections of the book seem a little frivolous to me. It could be helpful if you are feeling pressure to think a certain way and do not know how to articulate your thoughts or feelings about the topic, but no one that I know who has made a decision in that realm is going to have their opinion changed through the "facts and data" approach, on either side. It is strange to see how quickly the ideas spread from being a problem with college campuses to the primary topic of debate for the presidential election. What I really loved about this book was the freedom I walked away with to raise a child outside of cultural exceptions to become strong independent individuals. I want to become the man who can do for my children what my Dad did for me. If anyone would like to come to me and tell me what my Dad did for me was a mistake, child abuse, or unnecessarily dangerous, they better come correct.

Personal context here:I was born in 1994, so I am at that awkward spot in-between millennial and GenZ, however, I was in college during the time frame that most of the book focuses on, graduating in 2017 with a degree in childhood and education. It is a very liberal school, and I got to witness the best of activism. I saw and participated in a student-led program to teach and empower fellow students on how to recognize sexual violence and how to protect each other. Several other student-led programs too, which focused on empowering the community - foster children, children in juvenile detention, homelessness, the elderly, etc. And, I saw a large Facebook platform where students of color could anonymously tell their stories of racism and intolerance in the community - in reaction to the recruitment lie the university told its incoming students. I saw the rise in education not just being about knowledge and preparation for the career field, but a call to action and activism. And it's inspiring and it's a good thing.The book focuses on a lot of topics I've been interested in for a long time. Consumerism, philosophy, politics, higher education, and children. So, why am I only reading it now? I don't know why, but I have this bad habit of thinking that if a book seems too interesting to me, it will probably disappoint me, so I should avoid it (fortune-telling). Anyway, I'm glad I read this now. I studied it like I was back in class and man, do I miss school.The core focus of the book is on those born after 1995 (old iGen, or Gen-Z) and who have been in college during or after 2015. It aims to explain several factors that have contributed to raise GenZ to be astronomically more susceptible to mental illness and mood disorder, and how colleges are now struggling to adapt to the increasing needs and demands of their consumers. Thus, they describe the trend of "safetyism," or the use of cognitively distorted thinking (a term borrowed from cognitive behavioral therapy) to protect the generation's health and well-being from childhood to college. And this distorted thinking is spreading across our increasingly polarized nation. This is also a book about "wisdom and its opposite", and its connection to cognitive behavioral therapy. They frame the book as a warning to the "three Great Untruths," which are very similar to cognitively distorted thinking, and how these well-intended Great Untruths are backfiring.The Untruth of Fragility: What doesn’t kill you makes you weaker.The Untruth of Emotional Reasoning: Always trust your feelings.The Untruth of Us Versus Them: Life is a battle between good people and evil people.The book touches on a lot of different topics to show how there isn't just one blame, but there are several moving parts that makeup how we - and the generation - got to where we are now. It's not just overprotective parents or protective policies; the left or the right; social media and technology; and not just the emotionally devastating events witnessed by this generation. And the authors try to provide explanations for many of the attitudes we see today towards issues surrounding things like social justice, equality, identities, police, political parties, and why GenZ reacts to them the way they do. They also give advice for how to raise children to be more independent, and how to give dignity and autonomy back to students of any age.You can read their original essay here, which includes a list of the cognitive distortions.

This book has a long title that probably sets out the thesis in too provocative of terms. The authors are clear that by "coddling", they mean "overprotecting." They then proceed to explain what they mean. This means that the "three great untruths" are being propagated through society, to the detriment of the well-being of people. These three problems are "Fragility: what doesn't kill you makes you weaker", "Emotional Reasoning: always trust your feelings", and "us vs them: life is a battle between good and evil people". They are careful to make their claims defensible (such as these are not being taught explicitly, usually), and try to stick to the data we have. I find their analysis reasonable. They point out that kids are not coddled in being lazy, they are coddled in being protected and that we now have "safetyism" as a problem. Safetyism means that we want to reduce all risk on some measure (say chance of a child falling and breaking a bone) by taking away beneficial things with low risk (children playing in trees and exploring the woods). They point out that crime is actually down, and so under most risk/benefit evaluations we choose the worse option. This seems to be true from my anecdotal experience, and they usher some data, but I worry that the data is fairly inconclusive by itself. They examine parenting, college, and society in general. I think they give defensible ideas for the causes of safetyism and some ideas that could help. They are put forth tentatively, and so I give them credit for not overstating their case. They comment on many of the cases of colleges having breakdowns (the protests against campus speakers, Evergreen, the Yale episode with the Christakises), and point out the mental health trends for college age students. Again, the plural of anecdotes is not data, but they are careful and I find their analysis fairly convincing. It seems college students nowadays are less apt to be as strongly free speech as of just 5 or 10 years ago. I also personally think that supporting free speech in tough situations is the right call, so maybe I am too sympathetic to their argument.Overall, I think they give a good, balanced discussion. They point out that many of the reasons driving us towards this situation are good intentions. My strongest criticism is perhaps that the data they bring to support their interpretation is never strong enough to go beyond likely. When talking about recent events, it is perhaps inevitable, but I think their analysis of screen time over 2 hours having a negative relationship to mental health is fairly weak (I was able to find a NY Times article saying that such a relationship is not established). They are not advocating for a huge change, but they are advocating for change, and so it's always better to have a solidly backed theory, and I fear there's is likely, but not beyond a reasonable doubt.I would definitely recommend reading it if you keep up on the changes on college campuses vis a vis social justice. They do not strawman sides. If anything I thought they tried to inject balance everywhere. The stories are disturbing by painting a picture of some movement by universities away from truth-seekers, but the authors are careful not to make this apocalyptic sounding (not all universities, and most would still say they are truth-seeking). The chapters all have nice summaries, as does the book, and so it is quite easy to see their main ideas. I don't think I can award a full five stars because while they are nuanced, some of the themes do feel a bit repetitive, and it feels to me as if they are trying too hard to come across as fairly balanced at times. The style is quite readable, though.

I decided to read "The Coddling of the American Mind" because I felt like it might explain the experiences I had during my time at McGill and MAN was I correct. Haidt deconstructs the reasons behind and implications of the growing trend towards campus coddling. In a moment when cancel culture has extended to firing data analysts for tweeting out studies that don't conform with the "woke" position to forcing an overturning of the NYT editorial board for running a piece advocating for a position most Americans supported, this is an especially important read.The book centers around three central "untruths": fragility, always trusting feelings, and a Manichean view of the world. Haidt posits that not only are more young people thinking this way, but that university administrators, parents, and more push these untruths. Internalizing these untruths leads to examples like Charles Murray at Middlebury, the Evergreen State saga, and the riots at Berkeley. Identity becomes weaponized in a way that bolsters tribal attachment, instead of bringing people together around shared values. Speech, framed as violence, becomes easy censor on campus. Spirals of polarization result and academia adopt a self-radicalizing lens that discards the importance of real discussion. Normally, a back-and-forth leads to institutionalized disconfirmation. But under a system guided by untruths, an echo chamber results. The causes are varied: polarization, anxiety, helicopter parenting, decline in free play, expanding campus bureaucracy, passion for social justice, and changing notions of justice itself (towards equal outcomes). I was happy to see well-researched explanations on these points, as they go well beyond the "political correctness" the right often laments. I tend to agree with most of the causes, and Haidt doesn't make them all out to be uniformly negative. In fact, things like "bias response" emerged from the right intention but focused on the wrong issues. He sifts through the nuance, for example noting the importance of improved safety devices for children while lamenting parents' refusal to let kids be more independent. This adds credibility to an argument that in the media is often overly simplistic. One thing I loved is how the author sums up each chapter at the end. Because it's a quick-yet-applicable read, it's nice to go back and review key points.To his credit, Haidt isn't all problem-no solution. He gives tons of solutions for parents, students, and school administrators. Granted, I think some of the "solutions" would be ineffective and some are very vague, but it's good that he proposes them. Other ideas, like cross-partisan events on campus, are essential to revitalizing American academic culture. This is something I work on in my own life. Indeed, our campuses and social spaces would very much benefit from Haidt's approach to discourse. I become more convinced of it by the day.

Though the title is somewhat provocative the text is not. I love how unbiased this book was. I kept trying to guess if the authors leaned one way or the other politically. I'm nonpartisan since I find it hard to align fully with either side and was beginning to think they might feel the same. When they finally stated they were both more in line with the Democratic party I was a little surprised. If I had to say I lean one way more than the other I would likely say that I lean towards the Republican party. I don't believe this matters much though. This book is not about politics. The problems discussed throughout this book are exactly what our nation needs right now.Haidt and Lukianoff describe three 'great untruths' being rampantly spread across America, mostly perpetuated on college campuses and through social media. The 'great untruths' are; what doesn't kill you makes you weaker, always trust your feelings, and life is a battle between good people and evil people.I could write forever explaining these untruths but it would be best for you to read Haidt's and Lukianoff's words. I'll just share a few words and terms I learned from my reading of this book.Direct quotes:“...turn down the tribalism and up the sense of common humanity."" Call-out cultures are detrimental to student's education and bad for their mental health. Call out cultures and us versus them thinking are incompatible with the educational and research missions of the universities which require free inquiry, descent, evidence-based argument and intellectual honesty.""... take the stoic response and remain unmoved. As Marcus Aurelius advised, 'Choose not to be harmed and you won't feel harmed. Don't feel harmed and you haven't been.' The more ways your identity can be threatened by casual daily interactions, the more valuable it will be to cultivate the stoic and Buddhist and CBT ability to not be emotionally reactive, to not let others control your mind and your cortisol levels."Thoughts I wrote down: An educational institution's role is to help facilitate critical thinking not to ensure no discomfort is ever felt. Discomfort does not equal danger.We as individual human beings are not inherently fragile. We are resilient! Let's not treat the youth today as fragile. Doing so will only cause them harm in the future.Give people the benefit of the doubt. Practice the principle of charity, have empathy.Hostile attribution bias = the tendency to interpret others' behaviors as having hostile intent, even when the behavior is ambiguous or benign.

This book was an eye-opening, illuminating examination of the current state of affairs largely on campuses of elite universities, but also more broadly our culture and the rising generation (referred to as iGen by the authors and the research they reference). I felt like this book put its finger on many issues that frustrate me but that I couldn’t even adequately articulate. I’m often exasperated at how annoyed/embarrassed/incredulous I feel towards the rhetoric and behavior of people who I actually agree with politically, and this felt like it was reading my mind and providing much needed context and explanation for why that is. The authors argue that several parties within the last few years have had harmless, even laudable intentions: students/young people with a passionate commitment to social justice, parents who want to raise happy, high-achieving, safe children, and university administrators who want to create an academic environment that serves its students well and fosters a culture where every student feels heard and valued. In pursuit of these noble aims, however, several trends have begun that promote counterproductive and sometimes destructive methods and modes of thinking to achieve those goals. They liken these misguided processes to common cognitive distortions found in cognitive behavioral therapy. It’s a fascinating hypothesis, and they have no shortage of examples to provide evidence for their theory. They’re on strongest ground when examining the psychological ramifications, with the sociological feeling more reaching, and the political being a bit dubious. And their focus is strongest when it’s restricted to the university, perhaps because it is a much more uniform environment than the entire country/culture. It was also very interesting reading much of their opinions after having recently read Robin DiAngelo’s White Fragility. Many could argue that these two authors are writing from a place of extreme privilege, and reaching conclusions that serve to reinforce their privilege. I’m not sure I’d ultimately agree with such an assessment, but there were a couple of times in the course of reading it that I felt it was rearing its head. However, even if that is true, I’m not sure that it actually invalidates any of the arguments they put forth. And regardless, they’re diving into such thorny but deeply interesting concepts that it makes for fantastic reading, and spurs the imagination on towards many more topics.

When this book was published, it may still have been possible to claim that cancel culture wasn't real and that the left wasn't attempting censorship; I think it's increasingly difficult to hold to that view when people are being fired from their jobs for tweeting peer-reviewed studies from black scholars that contradict common wisdom on the left, Mexican American men are being fired for cracking their knuckles because a white liberal thought he was making a white power sign, and a liberal woman who has been wrong before has an entire Twitter thread where she doxxes teens as young as 16, 17 years old and encourages her followers to ruin their entire lives because of stupid shit they've said online. People on the left lie and misinterpret what even their fellow leftists are saying in order to chase clout on the internet and look Woker Than Thou.I can't even express confusion about what's going on without being disingenuous, because it wasn't too long ago that I was part of this sort of outrage culture; despite my reservations about the viciousness I saw in some of my fellows, I rarely said anything to anyone. The biggest mistake this book makes is in assuming that this problem doesn't extend past college campuses - it does. Colleges aren't even the hottest locus for this culture anymore. This is the culture of almost every online leftist circle I've been in within the past eight years or so, hyper-focused on finding things problematic, unable to relax, treating every emotional reaction like a valid justification for claiming bigotry. My experience is biased - I am an extremely online person - but my experience is not terribly uncommon these days.I liked this book, but I'm not sure what else to say about it. What the authors point out as a problem in this book has mushroomed into absolutely bananas behaviour in the space of two years, and through no fault of its own, that's its weakness - it can't address what this problem has become because the problem has intensified to a startling degree. The advice the authors suggest (more unsupervised free time in childhood, teaching children to recognize and combat cognitive distortions, etc.) is fantastic, and hopefully, future generations will be raised with an eye to the problems of today; but it's a bit too little, too late. All we can do right now is hope that enough people realize how damaging the New Left can be to its own cause.

This is a 5 star book with some 2 star moments. First, the negatives. I don't think Haidt has quite understood the hurt and frustration of minority groups. He delves into this, but he never quite gets there. I've spent a lot of time reading about this, discussing with others, and pondering why someone could feel and act so strongly one way, while it presents to other people as 'completely absurd'. I tend not to assume people are absurd, and that there are reasons they're acting a certain way, but it's not always clear what their starting assumptions are. The video of Nicholas Christakis being confronted by Yale students is a pretty good example of people not getting each other, at all. Haidt repeats a lot that it's not true that what doesn't kill you makes you weaker, and he says that people shouldn't be protected from ideas, and college campuses should welcome diversity of ideas. While I agree, there's a strong case to be made that ideas have consequences, and minority groups are often the victims of the ideas of the powerful. Many 'ideas' have been couched as intellectual and academic explorations while in effect causing oppression and hurt to the less powerful. Haidt might struggle to 'feel' how this works, since he is not part of an oppressed minority. But if aliens invaded and subdued humans, and then wanted to 'discuss' topics that potentially caused more suffering to humans, would Haidt be so supportive of unrestrained philosophising? This topic requires more nuance, and probably more heart-to-heart listening of those on the 'other side' than this book gives it.But the 'good' in this book is quite good. Extra points for his summaries at the end of each section, and for giving practical solutions at the end.I resonate with the idea that colleges are not there to make people safe, but to make people learn. I see the dangers in over-protecting kids. Too safe is unsafe, and causes them harm in the long run.Haidt helpfully identified many examples of 'concept creep' and 'catastophising', and I'll probably incorporate these into my thinking more. I also see the negative effects of good v evil thinking. Good/evil is an essentialist concept. It's unhelpful, and doesn't actually reflect how people start their lives and then are impacted by ideas and experiences. People aren't evil, just like they're not good either. People do both good and bad things (according to a particular interpretation of good and bad), and people change. You could see this at play in the Christakis video - many of those students couldn't interpret Christakis' actions as anything but evil. If he forgot someone's name, he's obviously a jerk professor. If he smiled, it was a wicked, smug smile. If he stooped to talk to someone shorter, it was condescending. If he was quiet he was guilty, and if he spoke he was domineering. I think that essentialism combined with censorship is a great way to generate team loyalty. It's how I am with spectator sports. :) But it should stop there. In real life it creates a state of fear and conformity. It's like a throw-back to cave-man days. I don't necessarily think there's a solution to all of this. Total free speech may result in oppressive structures perpetuating. On the other hand, supporting every social justice cause at the cost of free speech may, like Haidt says, give opportunity for more oppression, especially through the process of groupthink and safetyism's resultant fragility. Neither ideology intends harm, but both effect it at times, and we have to accept that fact somehow and find a balance.

The road to hell was paved in good intentions, or so it seems. In this generation of protection and safetyism, according to co-authors Jonathan Haidt and Greg Lukianoff, we have created a generation of people who are no longer anti-fragile. As the concept of safety has crept into our emotional well-being a dangerous shift has taken place: intellectual freedom is no longer being protected. Through the well-intentioned efforts of helicopter parents, schools operating in a litigious society, and colleges responding to the tipped majority of fragile, depressed youth, we have not only stopped protecting intellectual freedom but we have stopped honoring our individual right to express ourselves and to seek truth through cognitive dissonance. Adding to this issue is our internet generation (iGen), where screens have replaced five key activities that were shown to curb depression: exercise, reading, spirituality, in-person interactions, and homework. In a study presented in the book, those five activities were inversely correlated to depression and they were shown to occur less in our iGen population. Growing up with the internet at their fingertips has reaped havoc on the wellbeing of the youth. So what can we do to stop this? We must fight against three Untruths as provided here:https://www.shortform.com/blog/coddli...Untruth #1: The Untruth of FragilityThe first untruth is that exposure to adversity or discomfort is inherently damaging. This is a falsehood—stressors and risks are necessary parts of human emotional development. And young people are no exception.Untruth #2: The Untruth of Emotional ReasoningThe second untruth is that you must always trust your emotions. Too often, emotional reasoning causes us to misperceive the world around us. For young people, emotional reasoning can cause them to feel intentional slights where there are none and strengthen the desire to shelter themselves from emotionally triggering experiences—even speech that they merely disagree with.Untruth #3: The Untruth of Us Versus ThemThe third untruth is that the world is defined by a black-and-white struggle between the forces of good and evil. Psychological research shows that the human mind is hardwired to sympathize with members of our in-group and fear and distrust members of an out-group.(from: https://www.shortform.com/blog/coddli...)Fighting against these untruths is our way to repair the damage and to set up a world that creates new generations of success and not failure. We must make a stand!

The Coddling of the American Mind offers a crucial summation of "where we are" as a nation. The book tears down the "Three Great Untruths" that have overtaken our public discourse: (1) “What doesn’t kill you makes you weaker,” (2) “Always trust your feelings,” and (3) “Life is a battle between good people and evil people.” The authors explain how these "untruths" are the polar opposite of the conventional wisdom needed to fairly evaluate opposing points of view with logic, critical thinking, empathy and open-mindedness, and are in fact based on various cognitive distortions.  The Coddling of the American Mind also discusses how tribalism is driving a wedge between various identity groups in this country. The authors do not downplay the realities of hate speech and verbal intimidation, but hail the virtues of the "sticks and stones" philosophy, where true strength and resiliency come not from "safe spaces" where people can shield themselves from speech they find distasteful, but by feeling "safe" in their own skin despite whatever someone else might be saying. Particular emphasis is given to Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which the authors maintain can "correct" the cognitive distortions that cause "emotional triggers." There is even a short guide at the end of the book that explains how to practice this therapeutic technique. Particular emphasis is given to the chilling of free speech on college campuses—the result of college students' emotional fragility and its resultant "otherizing" opposing points of view and the people who hold them. The authors make a strong case that the various developmental disadvantages suffered by the current generation of college kids ("iGen") was caused by excessive early childhood "screen time," overprotective parenting and the elimination of free, unsupervised play (with all of its attendant risks). As the parent of a college sophomore, this book spoke to me; I may have, indeed, been guilty of overprotective parenting.In spite of the polarization we are experiencing in this country—along with the threats of climate change and social injustice—this book ends on a positive note offering an optimistic perspective for the future. I would recommend  The Coddling of the American Mind to iGen kids and their parents, as well as anyone else concerned about the devolution of discourse plaguing our nation during these troubled times.

MARCH FAMILY BOOK CLUB BOOK: 2.75 stars. This was such a rough book to get through. It seemed dated and the entire premise was based on a few sensational anecdotes that everyone agrees are weird and unjustified, but then generalizes it for all students and seemingly, society. Without any backup data (at least not in the audio version)! And his solutions were nothing noteworthy and didn't even seem directly tied to what the problem was. Or, rather, any solution could be thrown in because it was so broad sweeping. And yet, so narrow too, dealing with college students, and only during a small time frame. And so much professor woe here (shout out to all my professorial friends!); and nothing seemed to be uniquely contributed by the author: no new research or experience or take, just a bunch of ideas (without accompanying data) he seemingly threw together to meet the page limit, that didn't seem connected or very insightful. His throwing in cognitive behavioral therapy ideas, bringing up depression and anxiety throughout because the co-author had depression seemed out of place. So much repetition as well....here's the six things in this chapter.....now here are the six things I just talked about in this chapter......couldn't get through this book fast enough. Fine points on the final pages: yes, learn CBT (or I also think everyone should actually go to therapy); yes, do meditation to learn mindfulness; yes, kids should go on missions/humanitarian service, serve in the military, or get a job before going to college (although, those in the work force appreciate kids starting work after they've had an education:)); yes, let your kids go outside and play; yes, read Adam Grant's book "Think Again" if you want real ideas about talking to people with ideas that differ from yours (oh wait, he didn't suggest this but should have :)).......reading this was so laborious. Maybe in 2018 when he wrote it (I guess) this was novel and cutting edge if you're being extremely generous? But it's not 2018, so.......

"Prepare the child for the road, not the road for the child."Lukianoff and Haidt provide valuable insight on where good intentions have brought us and what they are doing to the next generation. Parents are overly protective of their children and these protected children show their vulnerabilities when they go to universities, complaining about how they are offended by opposition or even opposition to their views. Lukianoff and Haidt argue that physical safety is essential but students should not be protected from people who challenge their views. If anything, it makes them better at developing their stance on things and at responding to criticism. The more impactful danger that looms behind this is that freedom of speech suffers. If there is anywhere that ideas should be openly discussed, it is at a university. If this is no longer possible, the polarization that is already happening will only accelerate. The two writers also provide very basic advice to parents who are raising young children by saying that it is important to let them discover things themselves and not resort to the helicopter-parent mode. It is good for them to look after themselves every now and then and build up responsibility that they will need down the line. It is exactly this lack of independence that shows later in life and makes them weaker, not stronger.
