The book ends with a few useful practical advices about how we need to risk getting "hurt" or offended in order to grow, at an individual but also at a social level. The message of this book feels very important to me, especially because there is so much going on around us and there is so much out there. It is vital to the survival of a democracy that we remain open to people who do not agree with us. We should think about raising responsible children instead of overprotecting them and sending them out into the world too vulnerable to assert themselves.

Most, if not all, teachers (and professors) choose their careers to serve the students, thereby serving the community at large. Over the last few years, thanks but no thanks to the media, the teaching profession has been highly politicized. The book has touched on many personal points: one of the main reasons I greatly admire a university education is the free exchange of ideas and thoughts so that people, despite their different opinions, can seek the greater truth and understand each other. However, increasingly, this key feature of universities has been threatened. The book nicely summarizes the various issues faced by students, teachers, and the rest of the education community under three “Great Untruths”: (i) what doesn’t kill you makes you weaker, (ii) trust your feelings, and (iii) it is either us or them. Of course, they are untruths for a reason.Each Great Untruth is inculcated into the mentality of a student, especially in their formative years of childhood, adolescence, and teenage years---unfortunately, setting them up for continuous failure throughout life while leading such a life with stress and anxiety; the book terms people with such life as “anti-fragile.” What’s worse is that students are increasingly deprived of the right tools to overcome those problems; whatever the “tools” provided by the schools and universities, in many cases, make them worse.This book analyzes the root causes of these problems and blames them on how parents raise their kids, social media impacts kids, and the political forces on both sides of the aisle. A common theme across these different pillars of problems is “safetyism,” where children are not given a chance to fail and learn (oh, that’s how humans used to learn, and so do artificial intelligence-powered agents, which outperform humans). Such “safety culture” creates a prison for kids to lead a safe life while preventing the liberty to make mistakes and build a fraternity of people who may even disagree with her opinion—a stark opposite to the “us vs them” mentality that we increasingly in many universities and in the society-at-large. How do we expect the kids to think outside the box if they are not allowed to think? How do we expect them to perform in the world of differences if we don’t teach them in schools how to discuss and argue with people who hold different opinions? The book is a must-read for educators, parents, and anyone else trying to unify the community, country, or world.

Hmmm so this book is about trying to explain why college students, who used to be defenders of free speech on campus, now are more likely to demand that certain speakers not speak on campus and see speech itself as "unsafe". The authors identified 3 cognitive distortions they think are common on campus: 1) What doesn't kill you makes you weaker, 2) Always trust your feelings, and 3) Life is a battle between good people and evil people. Parts of the book seemed a little patronizing (but maybe I'm offended because I'm from the generation that the authors are calling out), particularly when the authors seemed to be insinuating that if all college students used CBT, then their cognitive distortions of the world being an unsafe place would go away. I think in doing this they were sometimes dismissive of situations that are genuinely unsafe (especially considering what just happened at Waterloo). That being said, I think the authors did a pretty good job of differentiating what kind of speech is unsafe (e.g. threats of physical violence) vs speech that one may disagree with but doesn't make you physically unsafe. Reasons the authors gave for for these shifts on campus included increasing polarization, increasing anxiety and depression, paranoid parenting, and less free play in childhood. The chapter on how declining free play in childhood could be linked to campus trends was probably the chapter I found most interesting. Basically, they argued that unsupervised free play in childhood is important in developing abilities to assess risk and resolve conflicts. Since childhood now is comprising more of homework/test prep, organized sports and clubs, children are becoming less tolerant of risk, more prone to anxiety, less adept at conflict resolution (as they become more used to having adults resolve conflict for them). Anyways, if I become a parent some day, hopefully I'll remember this.

Absolute must-read. The authors articulate such an important explanation of the modern epidemic of anti-resilience in the rising generation.Their careful approach and timely warning about how to ensure we don’t set up the next generation for failure is compelling. (Apparently I’m a huge Jonathan Haidt fan since I also loved his book The Righteous Mind and I love the free speech organization he founded called FIRE.)The authors propose that students are being babied and coddled to encourage fragility that is neither productive nor helpful in engaging in a diverse society. There should be no such thing as a “safe space” on a college campus, intellectually. The authors praise the University of Chicago free speech statement which has proved to be a model for many universities. The authors make the argument that kids’ minds should not be fragile or resilient. They should be anti fragile. Much like muscles and bones. Muscles and bones respond to pressure, stress, and stretching in productive ways that strengthen itself. Without opposition, the muscles atrophy and the bones crumble. Wind extinguishes a candle but fuels a fire. Be a fire. I completely agree. They warn of “concept creep” when safety turns into emotional safety that should be equally protected with as much vigilance as physical safety. Or when words are equated with violence. This concept creep is happening again today (in 2023) with people saying we need to remove “violent rhetoric” in our language like “dodged a bullet” or “pull the trigger” or the like. “Scholars” are saying that this violent language is leading to actual violence instead of it just serving as a hollow, relatable speech metaphor to get a point across They also highlight the benefits of understanding cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and applying it to kids’ development. I learned that Herbert Marcuse (1960s German philosopher) is the father of the new left and the power structures prism. Based on his 1965 “Repressive tolerance” essay. The idea of intersectionality of the progressive left turns up tribalism which can be dangerous. And micro aggressions + identity politics leads to cancel culture and unhelpful virtue signaling. One possible summary of the book is the outlining of the three great untruths: 1) what doesn’t kill you makes you weaker 2) always trust your feelings and 3) the world can be divided between good and evil people. The authors ascribe much of the current collegiate coddled minds to coddling, overprotective parents. I tend to agree. They hovered and protected, rarely allowing kids to take important risks to grow and develop and solved all of their problems while under their care so that when they left the nest, they couldn’t solve their own problems and would turn to college administrators for help and intervention. This is a book I could (and probably should) re-read from time to time. Especially as my kids grow up. There’s a terrific section at the end of the book that outlines practical solutions for raising wise kids, maintaining wise universities, and ultimately creating a wise society. Including a lot of helpful resources. The authors espouse free range parenting, of which I wholeheartedly agree. Kids need space to roam, make mistakes, learn by experience, and problem solve and interact with their peers at varying levels of complexity. Of course, striking the right balance of protecting kids - which is a primary responsibility for adults - while allowing them room to grow is the million dollar question. But this book highlights the danger of focusing too much on the former and not enough on the latter. For instance, the crime rate today is no worse than in 1963 when kids were allowed to roam much more freely. Also, the fear of kidnapping is unsubstantiated and overblown. The book points to figures stating that the rate of child abductions by strangers has been unchanged over past decade and a half and fewer end in homicide. 90% of kids reported missing miscommunicated plans, misunderstood directions, or ran away. 99.8% of the time, they returned home. The vast majority of abductions are by biological parents who don’t have custody. Stranger abductions make up a fraction of 1% of missing children (roughly 100 kids a year in a country of 70 million minors). And of the missing kids abducted by a stranger in 2011, 4 out of 5 did not live in a home with two parents. 1/3 of the children abducted were never reported missing. In other words, they were kids who fell through the cracks. Kids today are much safer than we were growing up. Which is not what you would think if you watch the media or the news. With the combination of the crime waves in the 1960s with round the clock cable news in the 1980s (and now omnipresent social media news), it’s obvious why parents have grown fearful. This is the “availability heuristic,” which I learned about in another parenting book . The more we hear about certain phenomenon, the more we believe it will happen, even if the statistical (im)probability has not changed. So, Is it any surprise if parents do not allow unsupervised play and then repeatedly tell their children how dangerous the world is, that they then grow up believing that can’t operate in the world because they feel unsafe?The problem for those of us who want to practice wise parenting is that there is always an obsessive, paranoid parent just around the corner who “fetishizes” safety and reports children engaging in unsupervised play as child abuse. This is not theoretical. The book provides numerous examples of this happening all over the country. So parents who don’t want to be overprotective are dissuaded from doing so in some instances out of fear of getting CPS called on them. What a world. This book is also where I first learned of the Heterodox academy, which is an amazing organization committed to fostering heterodoxy in our institutions of learning. Intellectual diversity is so badly needed right now (for example, just 7% of journalists are Republicans). Even more so than racial diversity, in my opinion. Since racial diversity is not a good proxy for actual diversity. The book also highlights the “problems of progress.” Abundance of food leads to obesity. Hyper/over connection leads to mental health issues. And coddling and overfocusing on kids Leads to fragility of a generation. Those would not be issues in a world that is struggling to survive and trying to find food and sustenance and shelter.Finally, one of my favorite lines is that the authors anticipate criticism of their book pointing out their gender (male) and race (white) as undermining their arguments because they are racists or sexists motivated primarily by preserving their privilege. Their response will be (in the spirit of Mark Lilla): “That is a slur, not an argument. Mane and argument and I’ll respond to it.” Huzzah!

I liked it and I didn’t? I feel like it made many valid points about the younger generations and how we can avoid exacerbating problems and issues. The latter half of the book I feel like covered this really well and resonated with me. I also felt grateful for many things my parents did that were unpopular (I’m the last age in the Millennial category, but see a lot of crossover in terms of issues). Where I struggled was I feel like it was (1) a lot of ranting about the most extreme scenarios that happen in universities and media (I skipped a few chapters in the middle bc didn’t feel like it was a productive analysis tbh) and (2) it also was still coming from a white man on topics like gender, sexuality, race, social justice. Sooo… while maybe the current methods aren’t the best/right ways of going about things, the author has zero experience in these fields, so drawing attention to them from a place of privilege could widen the gap and make it harder for marginalized groups to gain any ground in terms of equity. Sure, Title IX might make it hard for men’s crew teams to get funding/interest and there might not be as many athletes for women’s crew teams, but how much of that is culturally engrained in young girls who are pushed to be ballerinas and gymnasts? I don’t feel like the author gave much recognition to the pre-existing social systems/gendered expectations that these (definitely imperfect) programs, like Title IX, are attempting to improve. I would apply the same arguments to mental disorders — while rates are certainly on the rise due to the internet, does the pervasive nature of the internet simply call attention to a preexisting and silent challenge? (I say this as a person with a long family history of severe psychological disorders on both sides of my family and think it’s a mix of the two). While I can bitch and moan about the contents of this book, it obviously made me think a lot, so I think it did it’s job.

I discovered Mr. Haidt through his brilliant Ted Talk about political orientation and moral reasoning. From there, I found a video recording of a talk he gave at The Pennsylvania State University about the idea that the unique combination of safetyism and social media is radically reshaping the environment of universities and society. This book follows that talk more or less exactly.Working in education, I notice many of the trends Lukianoff and Haidt mention in the book. Things that stand out in particular relief are concept creep, severe anxiety about everyday stressors, and a number of the ‘Great Untruths’ mentioned by the authors.I think this book has a lot to offer anyone involved in academia, anyone who works in education, and anyone who has a kid really. The book sorts through big trends and offers some interesting insight into the psychology and the causes of these oftentimes harmful shifts.What I am more hesitant about is the book itself. I could have done with a bit less repetition. I get that this was built on the article originally published in The Atlantic, and perhaps there was some pressure to really bolster the article with additional information, but many introductory sections in chapters felt redundant. I also felt somewhat wary of the examples used in a number of sections. Certainly there are many, many examples of emotional, somewhat ignorant actions on the part of undergraduates (who probably have good intentions in their hearts but act in terribly misguided and childish ways); the authors point to these moments too often. This is low-hanging fruit and I would have liked to see some more nuanced examples perhaps...Overall, a great analysis of trends and some good practical advice regarding how to counteract some of the more harmful aspects of modern education.

To my thinking, THE CODDLING OF THE AMERICAN MIND is really two books which I would rate very differently and as such the average overall rating (three stars) is misleading. The first three chapters are excellent and I would rate that portion of the book as four or five stars. They delineate the root causes behind many of the disturbing trends one sees in the thinking and conduct of undergraduates today and analyzes these causes in terms of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). They distill their observations and recommendations into three lies and about nine pit falls in thinking CBT attempts to counteract. I found these ideas very helpful and continue to use them to analyze my own thinking. I will read these chapters over and over again.I am much less sanguine about the second part of the book which provides anecdotes, supposedly in support of the early chapters. Reiterating the events at Evergreen State College was useful, but for most of the anecdotes and discussion, I found that the authors broke their own rules. They used labeling extensively without clearly defining their labels. Many of the labels were highly pejorative, yet as far as I could see the authors did not explain why the labels were appropriate. They seemed to engage in mind reading (another of the pitfalls) in that they seemed confident they knew what motivated the various non-university groups which they also seemed to blame for the anxiety-ridden undergraduate mindset.When I finished and thought about what I had read, it seemed to me the authors were aiming for an “equality of blame” in their analysis of the anecdotes. This made no sense to me. The university administrations establish codes of conduct, enforce them, hire faculty, permit or exclude external speakers, and ultimately decide if they will support or not support teachers and students that are under attack for their views. Similarly the reading lists, course work, examinations, and grading are carried out by the faculty. Furthermore professors, by their own conduct and the way they approach questions provide examples to the students on how one should behave as one purses truth in an unbiased and objective manner. It seems ludicrous to me to argue that outside forces or groups who have trouble even getting an invited speaker onto campus can share equal culpability for how students are turning out.In summary, the early chapter are excellent and deserve a rating of four or five stars. The rest of the book, to my mind deserves only one or two stars. The average or overall rating, is perhaps, 2.5 to 3 stars.

This book spoke to me. Sometimes subtly, other times explosively. In many ways my childhood was analyzed and dissected throughout this book. The authors showcased how much of the iGen experience is filled with modes of "safetyism." These modes of safetyism stifle the ability for older members of this generation to handle conflict, understand their emotions, and respond to opposing viewpoints effectively. At first, I believed myself to be immune from these generalizations about my generation. However, as I self-assessed my middle/high school/college behavior I realized how much work I needed to do. Many times I would invite debate/discussion about controversial issues; however, I would tend to downplay the other sides arguments or engage in logical fallacies to bolster my own position. My emotions/thoughts tended to drift towards sadness, anxiety, or deep seated worry about my future. This book addressed many of these internal struggles by explaining how society unconsciously tends to promote three untruths about life (trust your feelings, tough experiences produce weakness, and the world is divided between wholly good and wholly evil people). I have seen these untruths in my own life, and in my experiences with other people from all sides of the political spectrum. I have seen these untruths at the Heritage Foundation, Teach for America, middle schools, my college, and many churches! I enjoyed how the authors did not limit their analysis to explaining how these Untruths have pervaded society. Instead, they also provided practical recommendations for how society can change our institutions, children, and universities for the better. Great book outlining the importance of free speech, intellectual thought, and the effects of safetyism on children!

I really enjoyed this book. Haidt and Lukianoff identify a possible root to modern culture's propensity toward cancel culture and partisan divides. In my mind, they established that a problem exists with emotional immaturity. Students are far more likely to be offended than in previous generations and they are more likely to view challenging ideas as offensive. This clutters a landscape like a college campus which is supposed to be about the free exchange of ideas. Universities should be the place where ideas are challenged and people grow intellectually. The authors share some of the bone-chilling stories of campus protests of controversial speakers turning extremely ugly and sometimes violent. There seems to be a mindset that if you disagree with me or challenge me, then you are the ENEMY!!!! This is not helpful at all. It leaves no room for healthy debate where you actually consider the merit of someone's ideas. Intellectual discourse is stifled by shouting voices claiming that speech can cause physical harm. While words can cause emotional distress, this idea applied wholesale to any type of speech breeds a self-destructive and ignorant society. Haidt and Lukianoff place part of the blame on the parents of this generation of college students being over-protective. This hypothesis seems to warrant consideration. Certainly, I am more fearful of dangers than previous generations of parents. We grew up with lots of freedom as kids that my own children do not possess. This book has inspired me to help my children develop a greater sense of adventure. I don't want to practice "safetyism" as the ultimate goal. Kids need to learn from making mistakes. If I never allow them to fail, struggle, or explore, then when will they develop those skills? And from personal experience working with college students, it does seem that over the last few years emotional and social maturity among students has declined significantly. There are certainly other factors at play, which I think the authors would acknowledge. But at the very least, this is a thought-provoking work that confronts cancel culture and we need more works that help us develop thicker skin so we can have a society where healthy debate and free exchange of ideas is lauded.

4.5 stars rounded up to 5. As I was reading this book and finding it quite interesting, I reached out to a few thoughtful and well-read friends to mention how I was enjoying it. Each said that they were avoiding it because they had a problem with the author Haidt. That got me a little worried about what I was overlooking and failing to consider. But the more I read, the more I liked the book, loving the way that the authors laid out their arguments and thinking that something important was being said. I finished the book very impressed. I'm not sure whether the authors' contentions are _correct_, but I respect their effort and am excited to have this topic further debated.After I read the book, to further investigate Haidt, I listened to about four hours of Haidt interviews from various sources (admittedly, mostly friendly audiences). He seems like a reasonable guy to me, sufficiently respectable to be able put forth an argument and have others review and respond to it. I read some book reviews, and the criticism felt jumbled to me. With The Guardian's review, for instance, there seems to be some legitimate criticism there, but it's too messy and fragmented for me to really grasp on to. My favorite piece of criticism that I've come across is the goodreads review by "Mehrsa" below. In the end, the criticism pushed me away from the 5.0 star rating that I was inclined to give, instead pushing me down to 4.5.I'm very curious what others think. Let's grab dinner and discuss!Audibook narrator: excellent.

This book did not change my mind because I already wholeheartedly agreed with the thesis but I thought it was interesting to apply psychological therapy methods to a whole group. I finished my undergrad degree in May 2013, so right before all of this started to take off. All the stuff about Milo Yiannopoulus is so amusing to me. My book review for Dangerous is one of the top reviews on Goodreads but.....no one cares about Milo anymore and the 2015 Berkeley thing seems just embarrassing in 2020. If you're one of those speed reader types, there is an "In Sum" at the end of each chapter for what appears to be that purpose. If you have not read iGen, you should do so before reading this. I would almost call this work a response to iGen. With all that stuff being said, Zoomers/iGen are the only people who have ever vocally expressed concern about me being on my phone in a room full of people. "Are you okay?" "Are you feeling left out?" I was answering one measly text, but the presence of my phone affected them immediately and they were worried about my current mental state. Millennials, GenX, and Baby Boomers would never say this ever, to anyone.Side note on one of their suggestions: As a Children's Librarian & the Vice President of a local teen center for the past 5 years, I could tell you that forcing Zoomers to read iGen will probably not go over well. If you suggest that psychological problems stem from smart phones, their sole takeaway will be that you're a pearl clutching, crotchety 95 year old who was born in the nineteen hundreds. They will say "nineteen hundreds" to make 1990 feel like 1903. Lol.

3.5 starsOverall, I enjoyed this book and it gave me so much to think about. However, I had a few issues. 1. The formatting, it reminded me more of an outline for an essay or scientific paper than an actual book. Which is totally fine, it was obviously a conscious choice, but I found the constant headers and “in sum” at the end of each chapter very distracting and it ruined the flow of reading for me at times. 2. It felt like two different books that never quite tied together. The first book being about coddling college age students/young adults and the second was about not letting children play outside enough. I get that they were all connected, but I needed to see a chapter merging that gap I guess.3. For as much as this book talked about the benefits of CBT, the only real “guide” on how to actually USE it were to refer you to other books and one extremely brief appendix. 4. The evidence. Some seemed more anecdotal than anything else, and some stories seemed to make the opposite point. For example: talking about how children would actually be very safe to walk a few blocks alone and then telling that awful awful awful story about the little boy in Florida?!?! I know it doesn’t sound like it, but I did really enjoy the themes of the book and found it really challenged my thinking at times. It’s one of the books you should definitely take with a grain of salt. I’ve found with books that are adapted from essays or blogposts, I often just prefer the essay and find faults with the full book. Thank you for coming to my Ted Talk.

An astonishing book on the how and why of university outrage and, for me most importantly, the increase of identity politics. As a moderate leftist I became increasingly annoyed, after I noticed I started participating in it myself and tried correcting myself on it, with the call-out culture and moralististic condemning of everyone that does not hold your opinion or world view. I learned the hard way we must always listen to everyone's opinion, how hard or stupid it may sound to you. Having read the Righteous Mind and The Happiness Hypothesis the Coddling of the American Mind is a perfect example of the wisdoms of Haidts books put into practise. Although I truly loved the new perspective on our modern day political culture I agree with many critics that the book ressembles more an enlarged essay than a true book. I would've loved a deeper dive into more flushed out evidence and psychological processes. Of course, not everyone likes this so the writers had to make some justifiable compromises. However deep, or undeep, you may be entrenched into the politics or college life of today, I encourage everyone to read this book, just to make you see things from a new angle. Maybe even read All Minus One, an easy to start (and I believe free, online) book that features John Stuart Mills ideas and arguments on and for free speech. Together these books make a very strong argument for leaving the current culture of safetyism, call-out culture, uninviting speakers, public outrage and shaming ect. behind.

Fantástica reseña.Este libro es una excelente radiografía del polarizado panorama actual. Si bien muchas de las cosas del libro sobre los códigos de conducta universitarios y los problemas que están enfrentando en USA no se pueden aplicar directamente en el contexto mexiano, el transfondo y el origen del problema puede ser visto y experimentado claramente en México. Gran número de jóvenes estamos experimentando altos niveles de estrés, ansiedad y depresión debido a la falta de educación en el manejo de nuestras emociones y el enfrentarnos a las ideas contrarias a nuestras creencias. Muchos cambios se están llevando a cabo en la sociedad y la búsqueda del respeto de derechos humanos, la concientización ecológica y otros temas están separando y partiendo el espectro social de la humanidad. Y este fenómeno es estudiado a profundidad en este libro. No sólo eso, el libro tiene varios consejos y soluciones a cómo ayudar a dejar de polarizar estos temas para evitar conflictos que salen de control en los diferentes ámbitos sociales. Considero que es una excelente lectura para TODOS los que nos dedicamos a la docencia a nivel universitario así como para profesores de preparatoria, ya que te da muy buenas estrategias para atacar temas polémicos o controversiales. También lo puedo recomendar ampliamente a cualquiera interesado en conocer un poco más del contexto piscológico y social de la generación Millenial y Zenial.

I'd like to rate this book 3.5/5 but I'll just round it up. I first heard about this book from a podcast featuring Jonathan Haidt, who I was quite impressed by. The ideas of this book resonated quite strongly with my experiences at Berkeley seeing the call out culture and safetyism which was all quite new to me. The authors did a good job of figuring out the three great untruths that are relevant to explaining the shift in college culture of late and more generally throughout society. This first part of the book is the most valuable, the rest of the book emphasizes various aspects like examples of unfortunate situations that arose from such misguided thinking, more detailed sociological factors and guides for parenting and schooling that can help us reverse such trends.A lot of it would be quite relevant for parents to read to understand how to be careful of such things while bringing up their child, but I found myself skimming through such parts. Nevertheless there were a lot of interesting things I learnt about the travesty of American kids not getting enough play and being burdened by homework and extracurriculars that gives them a better shot at getting into college. It definitely made me appreciate my childhood more and hope that such trends reverse in time. My basic complain with the book was that it was too long for my purpose, I almost got everything out of the podcast I had listened to.

Well this took me forever to finish. A lot in this book I agree with, and a lot I disagree with. I think the authors' academic disciplines occasionally blinded them to alternate justifications for what they're describing. I do mostly agree with the main thrust of their argument. We don't do anyone any favors by trying to shield them from all harm and engaging with view points you disagree with makes you a better person and scholar. Also it is pretty clear that rates of anxiety and depression are increasing. I actually have had a similar experience to Lukianoff in that I was diagnosed With Severe Chronic depression (in highschool), went through CBT, found it very helpful, and was able tomanage my depression through college without regular treatment. I completely agree that CBT Principles can be helpful for everyone and that you shouldn't always trust your feelings. My largest sticking point is I find the argument that this is a problem for all of Gen Z hard to square with the fact that the behavior they describe on college campuses seems to almost exclusively happen in Ivy League schools orin libral arts schools in the Northeast or west coast. I'm an older momber of Gen z (born in the 90s) and went to college in the Midwest. I observed some of what is described in this book, but not much. And I experienced plenty of debate. I took a Philiosophy class where we spent two weeks debating abortion. Two weeks! I'll sum up by saying I saw a lot of truth in this but I also saw some overreactions.

My brother gave me this book last Christmas and I thought I should read it before this one. I’d been putting it off because it just sounded a bit grumpy and heavy. It didn’t help that before I started it I read an excellent top Goodreads review by a woman named Mehrsa who confirmed a lot of my fears about the narrow perspective of this book. I still like that review and think she has some really great points. But honestly, I ended up really enjoying this book. I found a lot of the ideas refreshing and it really gave me a lot to think about. It felt like I took a mini solo university course guided by a well-written textbook. I appreciated Greg Lukianoff and Jonathan Haidt’s perspective on parenting (even though I am not a parent) and the links they made between overprotected kids and the rising intolerance on college campuses. Yes, I think there were flaws and I would love to have an animated discussion on the whole thing. I also really enjoyed the way this book is framed through CBT and appreciated the final notes on it. They included a list of categories on distorted automatic thoughts and I have had many! It was a nice reflective process to go through them and look at ways to mindfully reframe my thinking. I would say my brother and I have pretty different views which made me wary of this book. But being more open to different perspectives ended up being kind of the whole point of this thing. It was truly a great gift.

Ten out of ten.This book is a wonderful example of how to approach a scholarly subject in a fascinatingly readable manner, and how to maintain composure - and wit - in the face of radical viewpoints and polarizing evidence. Lukianoff and Haidt, bravo!The authors weave together compelling threads from disparate fields and from their own experience, both personal and professional, to support their thesis that American students today are being ruined by the application to their lives of three Great Untruths:1. What doesn't kill you makes you weaker.2. Always trust your feelings.3. The world is divided between good and bad people.They then offer reasonable, practical methods of weakening or eliminating these three lies.I was drawn to this book because I've become somewhat pessimistic, even cynical, about the future of Western culture. Refreshingly, the authors emphasize that they feel the current situation is remediable and that no one is powerless before it.I recommend this book to anyone who is in school, running a school, or, for that matter, worried about the polarizing trends in modern Western thought.

If I had read this in 2018, it definitely would have been 5 stars. Looking at this book as a self contained argument as to why free speech and exchange of ideas has diminished on college campuses, I really liked it. The first three parts are excellent. One author is an attorney, and you can tell. He lays out three untruths that have pervaded college campuses, provides evidence for them (mostly anecdotal, but compelling and beautifully argued), and then hypothesizes how the current generation (college students from 2013 onward) were inculcated with these misguided values through overprotective parenting and the extremely competitive college admissions landscape.However, my feeling at the end of the book is that it was about the canary in the coal mine. The focus on the upper middle class may have been merited, but the events of 2020 (election, pandemic, etc.) revealed how these untruths are a lot more pervasive that perhaps they initially appeared to be. The bifurcation of safety and freedom was magnified in so many ways . . .suggesting to me that this book merely addressed the tip of the iceberg.

"The Coddling of the American Mind" focuses on a culture of "intellectual safety" on American college campuses and its impact on free speech and public discourse. The authors argue that overprotection and the suppression of uncomfortable ideas hinder intellectual growth and resilience among young adults and society at large. They identify three "Great Untruths" contributing to this phenomenon: the idea that what doesn't kill you makes you weaker, that feelings are always correct, and that life is a battle between good people and bad people. They provide a rigorous analysis of what got us here (for example, overprotective parenting, limited free play and political polarization) and suggest fostering resilience, embracing discomfort, and promoting open dialogue instead.I really enjoyed the book! It's easy to read and well-reasoned. I appreciated how the authors emphasized the importance of nurturing resilience and engaging with discomfort, rather than avoiding it, to foster mental fortitude among students. It also made me think more deeply about how good intentions can go arwy when it comes to protecting minorities.

This is a must-read. It has me so concerned for our future, and we're seeing so much of what was discussed in this book happening around us today. I'm still processing some of it because I very much believe in the idea of "when you know better, you do better." How much do we know better and that's why we do the things we do. I do think we've made life for our kids too easy. The road has been prepared for them and they have not been prepared for the road. I found it very interesting that they discussed how kids are growing up slower--not faster--like we so often hear. This may be some of the issues I've seen in schools. The book says students who are 15 are acting like 12 and when they go to college at 18, they are more like what a 15 year old would be. This explains so much of the need for a "safe place" to go on campus when someone has an idea that offends you. I love the discussion of a "call out" culture in this book, and I see that every day around me. This is something that permeates the world--when someone has a difference of opinion, then we must call them out, and almost shame them.

This book is a rather ingenious idea, that iGen is behaving so oddly on campus due to cognitive distortions caused by over parenting and poor education. They don't nail the hypothesis exactly, but they do enough damage to make this book necessary reading. As someone who always looked at university as a four-year paid vacation, I felt like these authors schooled my uneducated self on what university is supposed to be like and why it's important. There was a great deal of discussion on how proper education can teach you how to think critically, and why differing opinions are so important to that. While the two authors do seem to be classic liberals, they do also become very critical of where higher education has gone. Yet, they do a good job of explaining why that has taken place. I found their explanation to be fair and wholly bipartisan. When they start diving into studies of what happens to mammals without socializing play...man, it gets trippy. The cognitive distortions caused by new technology and different attitudes...it gets you worried for these kids. Highly recommended.

~4.2~HUTCHINGS BOOKCLUB MARCH 2023 
"prepare the child for the road and not the road for the child." 
 I thought this book was pretty good, especially taking in the fact that he was bashing on my own generation haha, but doesn't everyone? HAHA Anyways, I agreed with a lot and honestly, probably most of the points that come up in this book. I thought that the whole peanut allergy thing at the beginning was very interesting. I think I was really into this book because I was in psychology last semester so I felt studious while reading this book. Being in college, I feel like I could see a lot of the things that he was talking about and everything in this book just gets more valid as years go on (especially since covid) I think the bookclub meeting tonight will probably be at least two hours...so wish me luck hahahahave a fantastic tuesday! 
 "what doesn't kill you, makes you weaker"

This book can best be summarized as "the effects of preparing the road for the child, rather than the child for the road."Though most of the examples and research presented here are focused on the university level, in my opinion, Coddling of the American Mind is actually a parenting book in disguise. I listened on audio and though I saw firsthand this intellectual marginalization in college, I was nonetheless shocked by the marginalization of debate and discussion in favor of “safe” environments. But mostly I was caught by their discussions throughout of the ways we can all fall into habits borne out of never wanting to see our kids hurt or be at risk - but the effect of that means ultimately sacrificing our children learning independence and ability to choose a good life (in both the Biblical & Platonic sense).If I see you in the next few months, beware I'll probably bring this book up and not stop talking.

A very interesting book. Very helpful to understand the terms, definitions, sources of authority, understanding and actions of a segment of IGen that gets a lot of airtime on national news. A solid description of what is going on and why.As a Christian, I found the authors prescriptions for change lacking in a substantive foundation (confirmation bias, I know what you are thinking). We need to ground our understanding of humanity in something larger than ourselves (as image-bearers of God intrinsically worthy of respect and care). Because this is how I think and want others to treat me is not sufficient grounds. I really appreciate the authors desire to break the destructive cycles we are presently caught (and they in fact offer some very good ideas) but we now need a Truth that transcends human experience and reality and that lays claims on us all to live righteously and with integrity. The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom.

A very challenging and thought-provoking book that talks about how American culture is leaning into coddling the new generation. As observers of the US, we might be enamored sometimes with life there and it's good to look at it from another perspective. The book talks about how harmful it is to children when we protect them from all dangers and don't allow them to experience anything risky until they reach adulthood.I don't necessarily agree with everything the authors have said. Aside from the anecdotal evidence or how they dismiss non-physical dangers, they make some solid points. The book also flows smoothly from talking about the problems, to how it came to be, and finally what to do it against it.Actual page count: 269

Well this book aged...like milk. Section I and II: Why are the most liberal students at the most liberal universities so sensitive and offended? Let's take a broad brush to a nuanced topic and use the most extreme examples to clutch our pearls at how spoiled our young people are.Section III: turns out those liberal students were under actual death threats from the far right. Who knew? (Well, the authors knew, but didn't tell you until now). Add in a healthy dose of "kids these days" and "parents these days" and "back in my day" and hand wringing about various social ills and offer no new thought on how to help except a ridiculous theme about the Great Untruths (untruths that bear a striking resemblance to evangelical and Christian Nationalist culture by the way--a concerning factor that should have been explored) and there's the book.Section 4: some groundbreaking (/s) parenting and educational ideas such as: limit screen time, support more free play, more recess, foster critical thinking, etc. Middle class parents ALREADY know this stuff. This might be the 10th book I've read that advocates for all of that. We KNOW.

Meticulously researched, thought-provoking and fascinating. I am on the opposite side of the political spectrum as the authors, but I feel they did an excellent job of presenting the topic fairly and not politicizing it, in fact giving examples of wrongs committed on both sides. It is crazy to think that parenting styles so profoundly influenced university happenings and practices, and the change was so abrupt. I hope this work has had the intended affect on such in the 5 years since it was published. On a personal note: as a parent of iGen daughters, it was helpful to learn about the characteristics of their generation. It also really made me consider areas of my own life where I’ve believed the Great Untruths, and I appreciated the appendix on CBT as I totally recognize some of the thought distortions I’ve been guilty of buying into.

I'm not much of a non-fiction reader, so it was a bit of a slog for me to get through. However, that was not at all indicative of the book itself.It was incredibly well written, full of interesting info & stats, and definitely captured my interest as best as it could. Though it was geared towards parents & educators, I still found it very interesting, and it gave me food for thought about our society and some of its problematic ideas, or "great untruths" as the authors call them:- "what doesn't kill you makes you weaker"- "always trust your feelings"- "life is a battle between good people and evil people"Would recommend!

This is the second book I’ve read by Jonathan Haidt. It is much like The Righteous Mind in its dedication to being fair minded, but lacks the same detail and thoroughness (he has spent much less time studying this topic). He and his co-author lay out a context driven analysis of what they perceive to be a rise in intolerance for free speech on college campuses in the U.S. That analysis also seeks to explain the rising rates of depression, anxiety and suicide in members of igen. This intersection between emotional reasoning and polarization was the most interesting aspect of the book. The authors clearly and succinctly present the evidence supporting their claims and acknowledge where it us lacking. At times their claims were overly broad given the evidence presented. The book would have also benefited from a recounting of the historical trends on campuses that led to an increase in identity politics. Many are decrying this reality without understanding it is a direct product of racism and exclusion.

"Prepare the child for the road, not the road for the child"... a lightning rod of reason and wise scholarship on a number of hot-button topics. I teach college and still struggle with so many aspects of recent trends like safe spaces, microaggressions, and call-out/cancel culture. All of which I learned stem from generational changes, access to technology, and increasing polarization. These authors explore the situation on campus with a stunningly broad and sensitive lens, and then lay out a path for the future of child-rearing, teaching and learning, in which students are ready and willing to be challenged, not coddled.

Jonathan Haidt was the first person who spoke my language and also helped me view “the other side” with compassion and, most importantly, understanding. I am left leaning politically and socially. This book challenged me to think about things differently. I can definitely see how someone like my father might read this book and think “see, I told you some college kids are a big problem.”But because I trust Haidt (a self-described centrist who favors Democrats on most major issues), the book helped me to add nuance and complexity to my thinking. I recommend this book to everyone and especially to progressives like myself.

This book was so good. It reveals problematic ways of thinking that have permeated the minds of Americans. The thing is, it also reveals areas in which these problematic ways of thinking have permeated your own life. I found myself nodding in agreement at some things and being amazed at how my mind has been coddled over the years in various ways. This book provides excellent food for thought and gives outstanding advice that I intend to use if/when I become a parent myself. I would and will recommend this to anyone looking for a hot take that so desperately needed to be said. Worth the read FOR SURE.

An important book for these times. Favourite paragraph from the book:“From time to time in the years to come, I hope you will be treated unfairly, so that you will come to know the value of justice. I hope that you will suffer betrayal because that will teach you the importance of loyalty. Sorry to say, but I hope you will be lonely from time to time so that you don’t take friends for granted. I wish you bad luck, again, from time to time so that you will be conscious of the role of chance in life and understand that your success is not completely deserved and that the failure of others is not completely deserved either. And when you lose, as you will from time to time, I hope every now and then, your opponent will gloat over your failure. It is a way for you to understand the importance of sportsmanship. I hope you’ll be ignored so you know the importance of listening to others, and I hope you will have just enough pain to learn compassion. Whether I wish these things or not, they’re going to happen. And whether you benefit from them or not will depend upon your ability to see the message in your misfortunes.”

My opinion of this book was not high for the first hundred and fifty pages, or so. Though the content of it rings mostly true, the language is unpersuasive. The authors use, continually, the word "untruth" instead of "lie". They refer to "Wisdom and its opposite" rather than "wisdom and folly." The hesitance to bluntly make the argument they imply seems to undermine the argument a bit, especially since it's an argument for free speech, and the words they choose feel a little Orwellian. (If they chose "untruth" to contrast with the "truth" of Aristotle's telos, then it's more understandable, but even still, it feels weaker). That aside, the book directly takes on a cultural battle in higher education, and I believe it offers some effective practical tips near the end of the book, and it is rather philosophically sound, though suffering from a fear of establishing objective truth, especially in a political or religious context.

Interesting, but not groundbreakingThis book is well-written and has authors who are well-versed in the field and are familiar with the conflicts of recent years. If you are only vaguely familiar with some of the cultural changes that have swept the nation in recent years, this is essential reading. If, in the other hand, you follow this stuff closely and have read some of the previous work of the authors (particularly their Atlantic article), then it doesn’t break much new ground.

The coddling of the American mind tackles 3 great untruths that have taken hold of America’s youth, particularly on college campuses. 1. What doesn’t kill you makes you weaker. 2. Always trust your feelings3. Life is a battle between good people and evil people. My list of people who should read this book:1. College freshman2. High school Jr’s3. New parents4. Elementary, high school, and college faculty5. School administrators 6. College presidents and executive team members7. Individuals struggling with depression or anxiety 8. Politicians and policy makers9. Employers of young people10. Anyone not listed above

This seems like an important book: there are lots of books around now that explore the reasons for america's polarisation and the way young people, in particular, seem so intolerant, unable to hear differing points of view, determined to denounce anyone with a different opinion, feeling threatened and fearful all the time. A lot of commmentators tend to blame ideology - not their ideology, of course, the other side's. Lukianoff and Haidt take it back to thought patterns originating in childrearing and education. Specifically, three bad ideas that have taken root in recent years "What doesn't kill you makes you weaker", "Trust your feelings" and "Life is a battle between good people and evil people". With these patterns imprinted in people's minds, we have a recipe for polarisation and public shaming and mental illness.It's useful to look at it from this end of the telecope, I think, because it allows you to focus on the workings of your own thinking and break bad habits. Without that, I think it's too easy to look out at the world and think it's only other people's brains that are broken. No, it's yours too. It's everybody, really, to some extent, even if some people have it worse than others.

A great read, at turns maddening and enlightening; it has the feel of a thing that ought to be labeled "required reading"-- especially the parts on cognitive-behavioral therapy (a.k.a., Stoicism). It's one thing to 'name and shame' (for lack of a more succinct way of putting it), and Lukianoff & Haidt do this to great effect; it's quite another thing to propose reasonable courses of remediation- and the authors do this as well. I would energetically recommend "The Coddling of the American Mind" to the nearly-college-bound (and their parents) as well as anyone at all who gives a hoot about this fragile thing we like to call "civil society".

Fantastic book and every educator and parent should read this book. It is nice to see someone gather the research first and then work on their theories. Most people it do it backwards and try to find research to prove their theory. This book brings out a lot of good points. They are not bashing our youth but instead show how good intentions can go too far. Unlike most people they also offer suggestion they believe will correct some of the problems we are seeing. As with everything in life it is a balance.

I avoided reading this book for a long time because I thought it was just more social commentary. But when I heard that it was more psychological and incorporated cognitive behavioral therapy ideas into its analysis, I bought it, and I'm so glad that I did. This book is now on my list of parenting must-reads. The concept of antifragility was new and clarifying for me. The authors' take on the psychological factors involved in the safety culture we live in leads to great practical advice for parents and educators. I believe that ideas, not psychology, drive history, but at an individual level, understanding how ideas interface with psychology is immensely helpful. If you need ammunition in your resistance to unhealthy ideas in our culture, especially safetyism, this book should be in your arsenal.

Every educator, student, and social justice advocate must read this book. It’s a nonfiction book that takes a very refreshing stance on the first amendment. The authors explain their viewpoint in very logically sound arguments that helps the reader understand the magnitude of the problem facing our society: a culture of safetyism. This book is truly perspective changing and intriguing. It is the best book I’ve read in a while.

I was totally absorbed in reading this book, and found myself nodding along with the authors as they presented all of the “good intentions and bad ideas” that are causing a generation of young Americans to falter. I was actually surprised to learn that both authors tend toward liberal political convictions given their views in this book, but that was actually refreshing to me. The one thing that put me off was their nearly constant recommendation that CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy) was the cure for all the problems outlined in the book.
